startText:
Get housing advice

Answer a few questions to get advice about:

  • how to solve problems affecting your housing situation
  • what to do if you have been asked to leave your property
  • how you can find somewhere else to live
  • how we can help you.

You don’t need to give any personal details about who you are or where you live.
 

Worried about homelessness?

You should contact Lewisham Council’s Housing Team straight away if you are homeless now, or are likely to become homeless within the next 56 days.

Click ‘Start’ to begin the questionnaire:

questions.text: Were you given information to show that the deposit was protected?
questions.name: were-you-given-information-to-show-that-the-deposit-was-prot
questions.info: The tenancy deposit protection legislation requires the landlord not only to protect the deposit, but in addition, to provide the prescribed information to the tenant explaining how the deposit has been protected. The landlord must also give the prescribed information to any third party / interested party (i.e. someone who has paid the deposit on behalf of the tenant whether in whole or part). For example, a parent may pay the deposit on behalf of a student tenant or certain local authorities may pay the deposit on behalf of the tenant under a deposit scheme which they operate.

questions.name: were-you-given-a-written-tenancy-agreement-by-your-landlord
questions.info: If, when you rented your home, your landlord or the agent gave you paperwork which you signed then you have a written tenancy agreement. This is the case even if the tenancy has expired. If there was no paperwork then you do not have a written tenancy agreement. If you had a written tenancy agreement but you have lost it then you should ask your landlord or the agent for a copy.

No, I was never given a written tenancy agreement

questions.text: Are you a sole or a joint tenant?
questions.name: are-you-a-sole-or-a-joint-tenant
questions.info: You will need to look at your tenancy agreement to determine if you are a sole or joint tenant. If the tenancy agreement names more than one tenant then you are a joint tenant, providing the additional names have not been added later. If the tenancy agreement names only one tenant then you are a sole tenant, even if other adults live with you. Being a joint tenant means that all the joint tenants are liable for payment of all the rent and for making sure that the tenancy is not breached. It also changes the way you can end the tenancy and claim your deposit back.

questions.text: Do you live in a house in multiple occupation (HMO)?
questions.name: do-you-live-in-a-house-in-multiple-occupation-hmo
questions.info:
Your home is probably a HMO if:

  • 3 or more unrelated people live there as at least 2 separate households – for example, 3 single people with their own rooms, or 2 couples each sharing a room
  • the 3 or more people living there share facilities such as a kitchen or bathroom

An HMO could be a:

  • house split into separate bedsits
  • shared house or flat, where the sharers are not members of the same family
  • hostel
  • bed-and-breakfast hotel that is not just for holidays
  • shared accommodation for students – although not if owned by an educational establishment

If you rent the entire house or flat then it is not a HMO.

responses.text: I'm not sure. What is a HMO?

questions.text: Is your sole tenancy fixed or periodic?
questions.name: is-your-sole-tenancy-fixed-or-periodic
questions.info:
You will need to look at your tenancy agreement to determine if its fixed term or periodic. If your tenancy agreement states that the tenancy starts on a certain date and ends on a certain date, and you are within those dates, then you have a fixed term tenancy.

If your tenancy agreement says that the tenancy lasts for a certain number of months or years from the start date and you are within that period of time, then you have a fixed term tenancy.

If your tenancy agreement has a break clause then your landlord(s) may be able to use this. Unless the break clause is exercised then it remains a fixed term tenancy.

If the fixed period of time has ended then you have a periodic tenancy.

responses.text: I have a fixed term tenancy

questions.text: How much is your claim for?
questions.name: how-much-is-your-claim-for
questions.info: To obtain compensation you will need to take your landlord to court.  You can claim compensation (called damages in court) for inconvenience, disappointment, discomfort, mental distress and loss of enjoyment.  Damages for ill health caused by or made worse by the disrepair may also be claimed.  Finally you can claim for your actual losses (for example having to replace a carpet); these are called special damages. The first step is to work out how much you are claiming. You can get advice on this from Shelter on 0808 800 4444. The LawWorks Clinics Network also provides free initial advice to individuals.

questions.text: How much is your claim for?
questions.name: how-much-is-your-claim-for-council
questions.info:
There are three possible ways to obtain compensation:

  1. Under the qualifying repairs procedure
  2. By making a complaint
  3. By taking the Council to court. 

You can claim compensation (called damages in court) for inconvenience, disappointment, discomfort, mental distress and loss of enjoyment. Damages for ill health caused by or made worse by the disrepair may also be claimed. Finally you can claim for your actual losses (for example having to replace a carpet); these are called special damages in court. The first step is to work out how much you are claiming. You may need to get advice about this. 

The first step is to work out how much you are claiming. You can get advice on this from Shelter on 0808 800 4444. The LawWorks Clinics Network also provides free initial advice to individuals.

questions.text: Double check that your home is in a HMO
questions.name: double-check-that-your-home-is-in-a-hmo
questions.info:
A house in multiple occupation (HMO) is a property rented out by at least 3 people who are not from 1 ‘household’ (for example a family) but who share facilities like the bathroom and kitchen. It is sometimes called a ‘house share’. Most HMOs have to be licensed by the Council. You are entitled to have repairs done to both your room and any parts of the house that you share (for example the bathroom and kitchen).

If you have decided that you do not live in a HMO go back and choose a different tenure.

responses.text: Yes, I live in a HMO

snippets.description: Your right to repairs
snippets.data: You have a right to live in a property that’s safe and in a good state of repair. Landlords are responsible for repairs to the exterior and structure of a property including problems with the roof, chimneys, walls, guttering and drains. Landlords must make sure the equipment for supplying water, gas and electricity is kept in safe working order. If your landlord needs access to the property to inspect it and do repairs, they have to give you at least 24 hours’ notice and visit at a reasonable time of day, unless it’s an emergency and they need immediate access.

snippets.description: Who has the right to rent?
snippets.data:
You have the right to rent if you are:

  • a British or Irish citizen
  • a citizen of a country in the EU or EEA
  • a citizen of another country and have no time limit on your permission to live in the UK (such as indefinite leave to remain)

You can have a time-limited right to rent if there's a time limit on your permission to stay in the UK. This is likely if you have a visa:

  • for work
  • to study
  • as a husband, wife or civil partner of someone settled in the UK

The time-limited right to rent also applies if you have humanitarian protection, limited leave or discretionary leave to remain in the UK. If you have a time limit on stay in the UK then your landlord must do a follow-up check after you move in either:

  • 12 months after the last check
  • the date your permission to stay in the UK runs out
  • the expiry date of passport or other document that shows your right to be in the UK
  • The check can be done up to 28 days before the deadline.

snippets.description: What is the right to rent?
snippets.data: A private landlord or letting agent must do a 'right to rent check' before they rent you a home in England. This means they must check your immigration status and that of anyone aged 18 or over who'll be living with you.

snippets.description: Who is checked?
snippets.data: You and any adults living with you in the property. This includes your partner, grown-up children and any other adults who will be living there. Landlords don't have to check guests staying in your home. A guest includes someone whose main home is somewhere else or who doesn't pay you rent. Contributions towards food and costs such as gas and electricity don't count as rent. Checks aren't needed for children aged under 18 (but landlords should check they are aged under 18).

snippets.description: Get further legal advice
snippets.data: If you are not sure about whether you have the right to rent, you are refused a property because of the right to rent or you believe that you have been refused housing on grounds of race then you need legal advice. Contact Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453 or Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444.

snippets.description: What if I'm discriminated against?
snippets.data: It is unlawful to discriminate in the provision of rented accommodation because of Race. Race and racial grounds include colour, nationality, and ethnic or national origins. Members of particular religious groups, such as Jews and Sikhs, also form racial groups for the purposes of equality law. Race discrimination may be either direct or indirect.

snippets.description: What if I don't have the right documents to prove my right to rent
snippets.data: If your documents are with the Home Office because you have an outstanding case or appeal with the Home Office and the Home Office told you that you have ‘permission to rent’, the landlord or agent can check with the Home Office. It may take 2 working days to get an answer. You will have to provide your Home Office reference number. If you are not sure if you have the right to rent then get advice first.

snippets.description: Right to rent documents needed by Irish citizen
snippets.data: A current or expired passport. If you do not have a passport, your birth certificate plus another accepted proof of identity should be enough.

snippets.description: Right to rent documents needed for person with a visa, humanitarian protection, limited leave or discretionary leave
snippets.data:
One of the following:

  • A valid passport endorsed with a time limited period
  • Biometric immigration document with permission to stay for time limited period.
  • Non-EEA national residence Card, or
  • UK immigration status document with a time-limited endorsement from the Home Office.

snippets.description: Your rights relating to Health and Safety
snippets.data: Your landlords must have a gas safety check done every 12 months by a Gas Safe registered engineer, make sure any furniture they provide meets safety standards and ensure electrical equipment they provide meets safety standards. Your landlord must install a smoke alarm on each floor of your home and carbon monoxide detectors in any room with a coal fire or wood-burning stove, but this does not apply if you have a resident landlord.

snippets.description: Your rights relating to your deposit
snippets.data: You have a right to have your deposit returned when the tenancy ends. If you have an assured shorthold tenancy then the tenancy must be protected in a Government approved scheme. If so, you must be given information about this within 30 days of paying the deposit.

snippets.description: Your right to an energy performance certificate
snippets.data: At the start of your tenancy, the landlord must give you an energy performance certificate for your home.

snippets.description: Right to rent documents needed by person with indefinite leave to remain
snippets.data:
One of the following:

  • Biometric Residence
  • Permit with unlimited Leave.
  • Passport or travel document endorsed with unlimited leave.
  • UK immigration status document endorsed with unlimited leave

snippets.description: Your rights relating to rent increases
snippets.data:
Private landlords charge market rents. An 'excessive' rent is one that is significantly higher than rents for similar properties in the area. You can apply to a tribunal for the rent to be lowered if you can show the rent for an assured shorthold tenancy is excessive.

For assured shorthold tenants, your landlord can serve you with a legal notice proposing a new rent for the tenancy. This is called a section 13 notice. The notice sets out the proposed new rent and the start date of the rent increase. You can appeal to a tribunal if you don't accept the proposed increase, but the tribunal can only lower the rent if it is higher than rents for similar properties in the area.A tribunal may also increase the rent.

snippets.description: Your right to peaceful occupation
snippets.data: You have the right to live in the property undisturbed and to be protected from harassment from the landlord and anyone employed by the landlord. Your landlord should not let themselves into your home without your permission. Your landlord has to give you at least 24 hours’ notice and visit at a reasonable time of day, unless it’s an emergency and they need immediate access.

snippets.description: Your right to a gas safety certificate
snippets.data: If your home has gas appliances, at the start of your tenancy the landlord must give you a gas safety certificate.

snippets.description: Your rights to a tenancy agreement
snippets.data: You only have the right to a written tenancy agreement if the tenancy is for a fixed term of more than 3 years. A verbal (oral) tenancy is however just as valid as a written one.

snippets.description: Your right to know your landlord's identity
snippets.data: You have the right to know who your landlord is. You can ask the person that you pay rent to and they must give you this information.

snippets.description: Right to rent documents needed by EEA or Swiss national
snippets.data:
One of the following:

  • A current or expired passport or National ID card.
  • A Registration Certificate.
  • A document certifying permanent residence of EEA/Swiss national.
  • EEA/Swiss family member Permanent Residence card

snippets.description: Right to rent - COVID-19
snippets.data: Temporary changes to right to rent checks have been introduced during the coronavirus outbreak. Landlords are not required to see original documents and are allowed to undertake checks via video calls

snippets.description: Right to rent documents needed by British citizen
snippets.data:
One of the following:

  • A current or expired passport,
  • A certificate of naturalisation or registration as a British citizen.

If you do not have a passport, your birth certificate plus another accepted proof of identity should be enough.

snippets.description: Your responsibility relating to repairs
snippets.data: You must report any repairs to your landlord (or the agent) promptly. You must give your landlord access to the property to inspect it or carry out repairs. You must also take good care of the property, for example turn off the water at the mains if you’re away in cold weather. You must make sure your home is well ventilated (to help avoid condensation and damp). You must do minor maintenance (such as check smoke alarms are working, change light bulbs) and you must dispose of your rubbish properly. You must not damage internal decorations, furniture and equipment. You'll have to pay for anything you've broken or damaged.

snippets.description: Your responsibility to occupy the property
snippets.data: You must occupy the property as your only or principal home. This does not mean that you need to stay there every night, but if you are going to be away for more than a short period you should inform your landlord. You should only take in a lodger or sublet a property if the tenancy agreement or your landlord gives written permission (this includes subletting part of the property).

snippets.description: Your responsibility relating to running a business from the property
snippets.data: If you want to run a business from the property you must obtain your landlord’s written permission.

snippets.description: Your responsibility relating to smoking in the property
snippets.data: Your tenancy agreement may also say you need permission for smoking in the property. Even if it does not, smoking is not usually allowed in any parts of the building that are shared with other tenants.

snippets.description: Your responsibility relating to pets
snippets.data: Your tenancy agreement may also say you need permission for keeping a pet.

snippets.description: Your responsibility relating to other rules
snippets.data: Your tenancy agreement sets out the rules that you have to follow, which must be fair. You should read it and keep to the rules.

snippets.description: Your responsibility relating to your behaviour
snippets.data: You should not behave in an antisocial or aggressive way towards your neighbours, landlord and anyone employed by your landlord. As a tenant, you will be held responsible for the antisocial behaviour of anyone who lives with you or visits you.

snippets.description: Help enforcing your rights - repairs
snippets.data: If you have reported the repair to your landlord and they have not completed the repair within a reasonable time, then you should contact Private Sector Housing Agency on 020 8314 3020.

snippets.description: Help enforcing your rights - Health and Safety
snippets.data: If you have reported the health and safety problem to your landlord and they have not dealt with it within a reasonable time, then you should contact Private Sector Housing Agency on 020 8314 3020.

snippets.description: Your responsibilities if you are a joint tenant
snippets.data: In addition to the other responsibilities that you have as a tenant, if you are a joint tenant one person can be asked to pay the whole rent if the other person does not pay. This also applies to payment of council tax.

snippets.description: Help enforcing your rights - gas safety
snippets.data:
If you have not been given a current gas safety certificate for the property then you should contact Private Sector Housing Agency on 020 8314 3020.

To report a gas or carbon monoxide emergency, or if a pipeline is struck (even if no gas leak has occurred) call 0800 111 999 - 24 hours a day.

snippets.description: Help enforcing your rights - landlords identity
snippets.data: If you do not know your landlord’s name and address then you should contact Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453 or Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444.

snippets.description: Your responsibility to pay your rent
snippets.data: You must pay the agreed rent on time. You must also pay other charges as agreed with the landlord, for example Council Tax or utility bills.

snippets.description: Help enforcing your rights - eviction
snippets.data:
If your landlord has served a notice on you and is seeking to evict you then you should contact Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453 or Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444.

Be wary of revenge/retaliatory evictions which happen when when your landlord tries to evict you because you've asked for repairs to be done or complained about poor conditions. You're at risk of such evictions if you are an assured shorthold tenant.

This is because your landlord can use the section 21 eviction procedure and won't usually need to give the court a reason for the eviction.

If you suspect that you've been the victim of a retaliatory eviction, contact our Private Sector Housing Enforcement Team on 020 8314 6420 or pshe@lewisham.gov.uk

snippets.description: Help enforcing your rights - excessive rent
snippets.data: If you believe that you are being charged an excessive rent then you should contact Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453 or Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444.

snippets.description: Help enforcing your rights - unlawful eviction
snippets.data:
In an emergency you should contact the police. If you think that you are being evicted unlawfully then you should contact Private Sector Housing Enforcement Team on 020 8314 6420 or pshe@lewisham.gov.uk.

You can come to our Housing Contact Centre at Laurence House, 1 Catford Road, SE6 4RU, 9am-3pm, Monday to Friday except for Wednesdays when we open from 1pm to 3pm for emergency cases only.   

Alternatively you can call out council call centre on 020 8314 3020.

snippets.description: Help enforcing your rights - deposit
snippets.data: If your landlord refuses to return your deposit at then end of the tenancy, then you should get advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453 or Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444.

snippets.description: Help enforcing your rights - harassment
snippets.data: In an emergency you should contact the police. If your landlord or anyone employed by them is harassing you then you should contact Private Sector Housing Enforcement Team on 020 8314 6420 or pshe@lewisham.gov.uk.

snippets.description: Help enforcing your rights - peaceful occupation
snippets.data: If your landlord is entering your home without your permission or your landlord or anyone employed by them is harassing you then you should contact Private Sector Housing Enforcement Team on 020 8314 6420 or pshe@lewisham.gov.uk. In an emergency you should contact the police.

snippets.description: Apply for a Discretionary Housing Payment
snippets.data: You can apply for a Discretionary Housing Payment (DHP) if you are entitled to housing benefit or universal credit housing costs and these benefits don't cover your full rent. In making it's decision the council must be fair and reasonable and it is important you provide as much information as you can to help the council decide. DHPs can be backdated but are only paid for a limited period and it is likely you may have to reapply at the end of the period. The council will let you know how much you will get, this may be enough to cover all your rent or costs or just part of those costs. You do not have to repay a DHP. You can apply by visiting www.lewisham.gov.uk/myservices/benefits/housing-benefit/discretionary-housing-payments.

snippets.description: Costs - rent for a shared room
snippets.data: The amount of rent charged in the private sector is a market rent. Market rents depend on the size and location of the property, so by widening your search area (or moving to a new area) it may be cheaper. Rent will be due on the same day every month (if you rent monthly) or every week (if you rent weekly).

snippets.description: Costs - rent in advance
snippets.data:
You will usually have to pay 1 months’ rent in advance (although this might be 1 week if a landlord agrees to rent to you weekly). If you are on a low income, you may be able to apply for a budgeting loan or budgeting advance at your local Jobcentre Plus if you cannot afford to pay rent in advance. Find your nearest Jobcentre Plus.

The Council offer a Rent Deposit Scheme which can assist clients in securing a property in the private sector by offering financial assistance when paying the rent in advance and deposit. This must pass a few of the Council’s checks, but otherwise will be processed straight to the Landlord. If you secure a property and can demonstrate that it is affordable, please send over documents below to HousingSupport@lewisham.gov.uk for us to assess:

  • Energy Performance Certificate
  • Gas Safety Certificate
  • Tenancy agreement with landlord’s name, client’s name, address of property, monthly rent amount and deposit required.
  • Landlord/agency’s bank details including payee name, payee address, bank name, sort code, account number.
  • Proof of income (proof of receipt of benefits and, if applicable, last 3 months payslips).

snippets.description: Costs - deposit
snippets.data: A tenancy deposit protects your landlord in case you leave without paying the rent or cause damage to the property or its contents. Your landlord should confirm in writing what the deposit covers. This may be set out in your tenancy agreement or your landlord may give you a separate document that's signed by both you and your landlord. The maximum amount that you can be charged as a deposit is than 5 weeks’ rent (unless the annual rent is equal to or greater than £50,000 when up to six weeks deposit is allowed). If the landlord or agent tries to charge more then you should contact Lewisham Trading Standards on cer@lewisham.gov.uk.

snippets.description: Costs - letting agents fees
snippets.data: Letting agents are no longer allowed to charge fees. The only charge that they can make is a holding deposit of no more than one weeks rent. This holding deposit should be returned to you, unless you decide not to enter into a tenancy agreement. If the agent refuses to return the holding deposit or tries to charge other fees then you should contact Lewisham Trading Standards on cer@lewisham.gov.uk.

snippets.description: Costs - council tax
snippets.data:
You will have to pay council tax unless it is included in the rent (usually if you live in a house in multiple occupancy). The Valuation Office Agency (VAO) sets the amount of council tax you have to pay. If you live alone or live with someone who is exempt from paying council tax you can get a reduction. If you or someone in your house is disabled, you may be able to get your council tax bills reduced. If you're on a low income, you may be entitled to some help towards paying your council tax. This is called Council Tax Reduction.

For more information about council tax, visit www.lewisham.gov.uk/myservices/counciltax.

snippets.description: Costs - rent for a 1 bed
snippets.data: The amount of rent charged in the private sector is a market rent. Market rents depend on the size and location of the property, so by widening your search area (or moving to a new area) it may be cheaper. Rent will be due on the same day every month (if you rent monthly) or every week (if you rent weekly).

snippets.description: Costs - electricity
snippets.data: You will have to pay unless bills are included in the rent. The amount you need to pay depends on the supplier and your usage. If you change supplier you may need to tell your landlord. If you are struggling to pay your electricity bills or you get into debt with your energy supplier you should contact your supplier as soon as you can. They will work with you to agree to a payment plan you can afford. You should also get debt advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453.

snippets.description: Costs - gas
snippets.data: If you have a gas supply (for cooking or heating) you will have to pay unless bills are included in the rent. The amount depends on the supplier and your usage. If you change supplier you may need to tell your landlord. If you are struggling to pay your gas bills or you get into debt with your energy supplier you should contact your supplier as soon as you can. They will work with you to agree a payment plan you can afford. You should also get debt advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453.

snippets.description: Prioritise your rent payments
snippets.data:
Paying your rent is always a priority. You may be taken to court and evicted if you don't pay the rent. If you can't pay the full rent on the day it is due you should:

  • pay as much as you can afford
  • make a plan to pay off any arrears

If you have other debts get debt advice by contacting Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453.

You can look at maximising your income to help you pay your rent by exploring what benefits you might be able to apply for. 

You can complete a free online benefits assessment using www.entitledto.co.uk/ ;

If you are evicted for rent arrears, you may have a County Court Judgement (CCJ) against your name which will affect your credit rating and other areas of your life such as renting other properties.

snippets.description: Costs - rent for a 2 bed
snippets.data: The amount of rent charged in the private sector is a market rent. Market rents depend on the size and location of the property, so by widening your search area (or moving to a new area) it may be cheaper. Rent will be due on the same day every month (if you rent monthly) or every week (if you rent weekly).

snippets.description: Speak to your landlord
snippets.data: Contact your landlord if you're having problems paying your rent. Do not ignore letters or phone calls from your landlord or agent. Your landlord may be willing to come to an agreement about payments.

snippets.description: Costs - water
snippets.data:
You will have to pay unless bills are included in the rent. Most people are charged a yearly water rate. You should be able to pay in monthly instalments. Some people have a water meter instead, so the charge is based on how much you use. If you are struggling to pay your water bills or you get into debt with your supplier you should contact your supplier as soon as you can. Most water companies have special schemes to help certain groups of people or to help clear arrears. Watersure is a scheme to help people who receive benefits, have a large family or use a lot of water for medical reasons. There are also other qualifying criteria which you can find out more about by visiting the Ofwat website. You should also get debt advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453.

Thames Water also offer free devices that can help you save water, energy and money at home. Click the link below below to find out more:

www.thameswater.co.uk/be-water-smart/water-saving-freebies

snippets.description: Ask for payments to go direct to your landlord
snippets.data:
Housing benefit and universal credit are usually paid direct to you. It might help you keep your home if the payments are made direct to your landlord instead. If you claim housing benefit then contact the Lewisham Housing Benefits Team on visit lewisham.gov.uk/housingbenefit to discuss changing payments to your landlord.

If you claim universal credit then you can ask the JobCentre Plus for your housing element to be paid direct to your landlord. This is called a 'managed payment'. You can ask for managed payments if you have rent arrears or find it hard to budget because of other factors such as:

  • learning difficulties or a mental health condition
  • severe or multiple debts
  • addiction problems
  • domestic abuse

You may be offered budgeting support instead or at the same time.

snippets.description: Claim benefits to help you pay your rent
snippets.data:
If you are low waged then you may be able to claim universal credit or housing benefit. Universal credit is a means-tested benefit that replacing a number of benefits, including housing benefit. It includes a housing costs element to help pay the rent. You can only make a new claim for housing benefit if you have 3 or more dependent children or you are staying in a refuge or some types of supported or temporary accommodation.

You can make an application for universal credit at your local Jobcentre Plus. You are unlikely to get all of your rent paid. You can check your benefit entitlement at www.entitledto.co.uk.

snippets.description: Claim other benefits
snippets.data: You may be able to claim other benefits or tax credits, which will help you increase your income. You can check your benefit entitlement at www.entitledto.co.uk .

snippets.description: Claim housing benefit to help pay your rent
snippets.data: If your income is low then you may be able to claim housing benefit. You are unlikely to get all of your rent paid. You can check your benefit entitlement at www.entitledto.co.uk. Housing benefit can be claimed by lewisham.gov.uk/housingbenefit.

snippets.description: Benefit delays
snippets.data:
Universal credit claims take at least 6 weeks to process. You can ask the JobCentre Plus for a short-term advance while you wait for your first payment.

For housing benefit, if you have given the council all the information it needs to process your housing benefit claim then you are entitled to payment on account after 14 days.

snippets.description: Check how much rent you owe
snippets.data:
Mistakes can be made. Make sure you agree on how much is owed. Keep records of:

  • all payments made by you
  • any housing benefit or universal credit payments
  • rent in advance paid at the start of the tenancy

snippets.description: Speak to the student welfare advisor
snippets.data: The student welfare advisor at your university or college can help you with budgeting and claiming benefits. Most universities and colleges have a hardship fund for students struggling financially.

snippets.description: Finding a private let - windows or noticeboards
snippets.data: Landlords and those looking for flatshares sometimes advertise in shops, community centres, libraries, bookshops, newsagents and other community spaces.

snippets.description: Finding a private let - personal contacts
snippets.data: Friends, family, or work colleagues may know of places available for rent. Ask everyone you know.

snippets.description: Finding a private let - local newspapers/magazines
snippets.data: Most local newspapers and magazines will have a section with advertisements for rented accommodation and flat shares.

snippets.description: Finding a private let - advice services and day centres
snippets.data: These may have a list of local landlords, letting agents and lodging schemes; landlords may also contact centres if they have accommodation to let.

snippets.description: Finding a private let - online
snippets.data:
Landlords and agents advertise properties online using a variety of websites. Here are some of the most popular sites:

  • Rightmove
  • Zoopla
  • Find a Flat
  • Gumtree
  • SpareRoom​​​​​​

snippets.description: Finding a private let - letting agencies
snippets.data: Yell.com will have information about local letting agencies.

snippets.description: Your notice appears to be valid
snippets.data: Unfortunately, the Section 21 Notice is likely to be valid. A Section 21 Notice needs to be valid, before a landlord can get back possession of his/her property. A Section 21 Notice may appear to be valid, but we can look into this further for you, and perhaps still prevent you from losing your home.You do not have to leave your home straight away. Your landlord must first issue court proceedings. Before that happens you should contact Lewisham Council Housing Team on 020 8314 3020 for further advice about your options.

snippets.description: Costs - rent for a bedsit
snippets.data: The amount of rent charged in the private sector is a market rent. Market rents depend on the size and location of the property, so by widening your search area (or moving to a new area) it may be cheaper. Rent will be due on the same day every month (if you rent monthly) or every week (if you rent weekly).

snippets.description: Costs - rent for a 3 bed
snippets.data: The amount of rent charged in the private sector is a market rent. Market rents depend on the size and location of the property, so by widening your search area (or moving to a new area) it may be cheaper. Rent will be due on the same day every month (if you rent monthly) or every week (if you rent weekly).

snippets.description: Costs - rent for a 4 bed or larger
snippets.data: The amount of rent charged in the private sector is a market rent. Market rents depend on the size and location of the property, so by widening your search area (or moving to a new area) it may be cheaper. Rent will be due on the same day every month (if you rent monthly) or every week (if you rent weekly).

snippets.description: Claim housing benefit as a student to help pay your rent
snippets.data:
As a full-time student, you may be able to claim housing benefit if you:

  • are under 21 and not in higher education (for example, studying A levels at college)
  • receive income support, income-based jobseeker's allowance, or income-related employment and support allowance
  • have dependent children who live with you, or your partner if they are also a full-time student
  • are a lone foster carer
  • have a disability and qualify for a disability premium or severe disability premium
  • get a disabled student's allowance because you are deaf
  • or your partner has reached state pension age

You are unlikely to get all of your rent paid. You can check your benefit entitlement at www.entitledto.co.uk . You can make a claim for housing benefit by lewisham.gov.uk/housingbenefit.

snippets.description: Invalid section 21 notice - what you need to do next
snippets.data:
If you inform your landlord that your section 21 notice is invalid, your landlord may be able to take steps to ensure that the next notice they serve is valid. If there is an underlying reason why your landlord served the notice, such as rent arrears, you now have time to try and resolve this. If you need help with this or with negotiating with your landlord then you should contact Lewisham Council Housing Team on 020 8314 3020.

If your landlord issues a court claim for possession then you should complete the defence form saying why the notice is invalid.

snippets.description: Form 6A - Why is your section 21 notice invalid?
snippets.data: Your notice is not valid because your landlord has failed to use the Form 6A correctly.

snippets.description: Tenants options during COVID-19 outbreak
snippets.data: All tenants in the private and social rented sector are now entitled to three months’ notice of intention to seek possession from their landlord. Tenants must continue to adhere to occupancy conditions, especially paying their rent. Social and private landlords must continue to fulfil their obligations, especially urgent repairs. Local authorities are expected to continue enforcing standards in rented properties.

snippets.description: Homeowners options during COVID-19 outbreak
snippets.data:
Lenders should exercise forbearance during the coronavirus outbreak, by operating payment holidays for owner-occupiers and buy-to-let landlords of up to three months.

People buying or selling a private residential home which they intend to live in, during the current stay-at-home period should delay doing so until when the current measures are no longer in place. Lenders should be able to extend the current terms of a mortgage. If your home is not already on the market, you should wait to contact an estate agent until the current measures are no longer in place. If your home is already on the market, viewing should not take place until the current measures are no longer in place. Accepting an offer for a home that is already on the market remains feasible but the sale might take longer to complete during the current stay-at-home period. You should expect estate agents, conveyancers, surveyors and removal firms all to be supportive during this current stay-at-home period.

snippets.description: Rough sleepers options during the COVID-19 outbreak
snippets.data: People who are sleeping rough should expect to expect local authorities and voluntary organisations to offer help to come inside, so you can be safeguarded from the COVID-19. Day centres might be closed and street encampments may be dispersed due to these being places where there is a higher risk of transmission of COVID-19. You can expect to be offered support medical treatment along with getting basic needs met, such as a provision of food. You expect these arrangements to last until the coronavirus outbreak has passed.

snippets.description: Domestic abuse surviviors and COVID-19 outbreak
snippets.data:
Refuges and other forms of domestic abuse safe accommodation will continue to remain open. People who need to flee their home due to domestic abuse or threats of domestic abuse should do so.

Households occupying refuges and other forms of domestic abuse safe accommodation should self-isolate in line with general national guidance. People need to flee their home due to violence or threats of violence should do so.

snippets.description: Coronavirus update
snippets.data:
You're entitled to at least 3 months' notice if you get a notice between 26 March and 30 September 2020 due to the COVID-19 outbreak.

The longer notice period won't apply if you got your notice before 26 March. But all further court action for eviction has been suspended for 90 days, so your landlord or lender can't take things any further until at least the end of June.

snippets.description: Eviction proceedings - COVID-19
snippets.data:
The court service has suspended all ongoing housing possession actions against homeowners and tenants/licensees, from 27th March 2020 for 90 days, until no later than 30th October 2020.

Private landlords are required to adhere to The Pre-Action Protocol for Possession Claim by Social Landlords.

snippets.description: Help with housing costs - COVID-19
snippets.data: Housing Benefit and Universal Credit have been increased so that the Local Housing Allowance rates will cover at 30% of market rents within a Broad Rental Market Area.

snippets.description: What is an assured tenancy?
snippets.data:
Assured tenancies with private landlords are not very common. They are lifetime tenancies. A tenancy with a private landlord is usually an assured tenancy if:

  • your original tenancy started between 15 January 1989 and 27 February 1997
  • your landlord didn't give you an agreement or notice that it was an Assured Shorthold Tenancy (AST)
  • you don't share any rooms with your landlord and they live elsewhere

An assured tenancy means that you have good security of tenure and you should think very carefully before giving up this tenancy.

snippets.description: What is a regulated tenancy?
snippets.data: A regulated tenancy is a long-term tenancy with a private landlord. You probably have a regulated tenancy if you pay rent to a private landlord and your tenancy started before 15 January 1989. You could be a regulated tenant if you later signed a new tenancy agreement after that date with the same landlord, even if it is at a different address. You won't be a regulated tenant if you've lived in the same property as your landlord since your tenancy started.

snippets.description: Credit checks
snippets.data:
Many landlords run a credit check to see if you've had problems paying bills in the past. They check information held by credit reference agencies’ (CRAs). The three main CRAs are Experian, Equifax and Callcredit. Your landlord or agent will need your written permission to perform this check. If you refuse permission they then can refuse to rent to you. If you have a bad credit history, be honest about it before you pay any fees or you risk losing them if you fail the check. If you have a poor credit history you could be asked to provide a larger deposit, pay more rent in advance or find a guarantor. You can check your own credit score on the following websites:

  • Equifax
  • Experian
  • Noddle

snippets.description: Rights of regulated tenants
snippets.data: Regulated tenants have strong tenancy rights. Your landlord must get a possession order from the court to evict you. The court can only make a possession order if your landlord proves a legal reason for evicting you. In most cases, the court will consider if it's reasonable to make a possession order even if the landlord has a legal reason to evict. It's illegal eviction if your landlord tries to evict you without getting a court order. In an emergency, you should contact the police. If your landlord or anyone employed by them is harassing you then you should contact Private Sector Housing Enforcement Team on 020 8314 6420 or pshe@lewisham.gov.uk.

snippets.description: Regulated tenancy - why your section 21 notice is not valid
snippets.data: If you have a regulated tenancy, there is no circumstance where your landlord can serve a valid section 21 notice.

snippets.description: What is the the correct notice period?
snippets.data: Your landlord must give you 2 clear months notice. For example, on the Form 6A, if the date in Section 4 is 20/02/2019, then the date in Section 2 must be 20/04/2019 or later).

snippets.description: Notice period - Why is your section 21 notice invalid?
snippets.data: Your notice is not valid because your landlord has not used the correct notice period.

snippets.description: Rights of assured tenants
snippets.data: Your landlord must give you notice on a special form and then get a possession order from the court. You can only be evicted if your landlord can prove a legal reason to the court. In some cases the court must also decide whether it is reasonable for you to be evicted. It's illegal eviction if your landlord tries to evict you without getting a court order. In an emergency, you should contact the police. If your landlord or anyone employed by them is harassing you then you should contact Private Sector Housing Enforcement Team on 020 8314 6420 or pshe@lewisham.gov.uk.

snippets.description: Assured tenancy - why your section 21 notice is not valid?
snippets.data: If you have an assured tenancy, there is no circumstance where your landlord can serve a valid section 21 notice.

snippets.description: Renewing your sole fixed term tenancy
snippets.data:
You do not need to renew your tenancy until the fixed term comes to an end. Even then there is no need to renew your tenancy, as you will automatically become a periodic tenant. It may however be necessary to renew your tenancy if your landlord insists that you do, so that you keep your home.

A fixed term tenancy binds both the tenant and the landlord(s), so it cannot be ended by either party until the fixed term ends. When the fixed term of a tenancy comes to an end the tenancy continues on the same terms as a periodic tenancy. A tenancy can only be ended by the service of the correct notice followed by a court order.

snippets.description: No tenancy agreement - You do not need to renew your tenancy
snippets.data: You have a periodic tenancy and this will continue on the same terms until it is ended by either the tenant or landlord(s). A landlord must serve the correct notice followed by a court order. If your landlord wants to increase the rent s/he will have to serve a Notice of Rent Increase. If you get such a Notice then you should contact Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453 or Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444 for further advice.

snippets.description: Report poor housing conditions to the Council - may make notice invalid
snippets.data:
If the conditions in your home are poor then you should report this to the Council. We have a responsibility to make sure that housing is of a good standard. Please contact Private Sector Housing Agency on 020 8314 3020.

Service of an improvement notice may mean that the landlord cannot evict you using a section 21 notice.

snippets.description: Method of service - Why your section 21 notice may be invalid
snippets.data:
Some landlords do not take into consideration how the notice is served upon the tenant and fail to add a sufficient amount of time to reflect their method of delivery.

Example, the landlord completes the Form 6A on 01/02/2019 and uses this date in Section 4. If the landlord uses the date of 01/04/2019 in Section 2 (exactly two months later) but posts the letter - that notice is invalid. There are different time periods for each method of delivery.

The deemed date of services for first class post is two working days after the day it was posted. E.g. if the landlord posts on a Thursday, the date of service would be the following Monday. The landlord must allow sufficient time for their chosen method of delivery. For more help on calculating whether your notice is valid, contact Lewisham Council Housing Team on 020 8314 3020.

snippets.description: Unlicensed HMO - Why your Notice may be invalid
snippets.data: If an HMO requires a licence but does not have one, any Notice served under section 21 will be invalid. If the landlord makes an application for a licence or is given a temporary exemption by the Council, they will be able to serve a valid Notice.

snippets.description: Responding to adverts
snippets.data: It is important to respond to advertisements as quickly as possible to avoid disappointment. Demand for housing is high, so vacancies can be taken up the same day they are advertised.

snippets.description: Rent guarantor
snippets.data:
You might be asked to provide a guarantor if you haven't rented before, if you cannot provide references or your credit history is bad. A guarantor is someone who agrees to pay the rent if you do not.

Your parents or someone else in your family or a very close friend can act as a guarantor for you. They are liable to pay all the rent if you do not pay.

snippets.description: Viewing a property
snippets.data:
You should view a property to check that it exists and is in good condition. You should not commit to taking a property until you have seen it. For safety reasons and to get another perspective, it is best to take someone with you.

Arrive 5 minutes before the viewing time. Be polite and ask questions about any issues, rather than making demands. Show that you are keen. Answer questions, but don’t volunteer too much information.

Things to check on looking round prospective housing are:

  • Doors lock properly.
  • Heating, lighting and plumbing in good working order.
  • All gas appliances have a Gas Safe certificate. This is a legal requirement.
  • Furniture in decent condition.
  • Signs of disrepair.
  • Personal safety in surrounding neighbourhood.
  • Other tenants if accommodation is shared.
  • How bills and council tax are paid.

You are likely to be asked for:

  • recent bank statements
  • your pay slips or your accounts if you work for yourself
  • proof of benefit awards
  • your employment contract

Landlords and letting agents will also ask you to prove you have the right to rent. You'll be asked to provide your passport, ID card or other documents.

snippets.description: References
snippets.data:
You will be asked to give references to show you can afford the property, and will be a good tenant. You will usually have to give a reference from:

  • your current landlord and previous landlords
  • your employer - to show you have a job and it will continue

snippets.description: Proof of income
snippets.data:
A landlord will want proof that you will be able to afford the rent. They could ask to see:

  • your employment contract
  • recent payslips or bank statements
  • a letter from your employer confirming you work for them and how long for
  • accounts or bank statements if you're self-employed
  • award letters if claiming benefits

snippets.description: Identification
snippets.data: Your landlord or letting agent will want to see photo ID, such as a driving licence or passport.If you don't have photo ID, a signed bank card or a utility bill from your current home may be enough.

snippets.description: Renewing your joint periodic tenancy
snippets.data:
You do not necessarily need to renew your tenancy. If there was a fixed term which has come to an end, you automatically became periodic tenants. It may however be necessary to renew your tenancy if your landlord insists that you do, so that you keep your home.

If you want to renew your tenancy as a joint tenancy, both (or all if there are more than two) of the joint tenants should sign the new tenancy agreement.

A tenancy continues on the same terms until it is ended by either the tenants or landlord(s). A landlord must serve the correct notice followed by a court order. Some landlords an agents insist on renewing the tenancy when the fixed term expires and this may be necessary to keep you home. An agent is entitled to charge a fee for renewing a tenancy only if the fee is clearly set out the fees they charge on their websites and in their offices. They must not mislead you. They must clearly describe the cost of each fee (including VAT) and what the fee covers.

If the reason that the landlord or agent wants to renew the tenancy is to increase the rent then you need to consider whether or not you can afford the new rent. You should try and negotiate a rent that you can afford. You should also consider whether or not you could rent another property for the same of cheaper rent. Ultimately if you cannot afford the rent then you should not sign the new tenancy.

Being a joint tenant means that all the joint tenants are liable for payment of all the rent and for making sure that the tenancy is not breached. It also changes the way you can end the tenancy and claim your deposit back.

snippets.description: Ending your sole tenancy - monthly periodic
snippets.data:
You must give your landlord notice in writing to end a periodic tenancy. This is called a 'notice to quit'. You must give the correct date for when your notice period ends, otherwise it will not be valid.

To work out the amount of notice you need to check your tenancy agreement. If it sets out the amount of notice you must give your landlord, follow what your agreement says. If your tenancy agreement doesn't set out a notice period then you must give your landlord at least 1 month's notice. Your notice must end on the first day or last day of your tenancy period. This is not always the date you pay your rent so check your agreement carefully.

For example, if your tenancy started on 10 September:

  • then the last day of your tenancy period will be 9th of the month
  • the first day of the next tenancy period will be 10th of the month

It's easier to calculate the final month's rent if you give notice to end on the last day of the tenancy period.

Your notice should include:

  • your name and address
  • your landlord's name and address
  • the date your notice period ends

You could also include a forwarding address for your landlord to return your tenancy deposit. If you deliver the letter to your landlord by hand, ask for a receipt. If you post it, use recorded delivery so you can prove it arrived. Don't send an email unless your tenancy says you can, otherwise your notice won't be valid.

The alternative way to end your tenancy is by reaching an agreement with the landlord (a process known as surrender). You should make sure that any agreement is recorded in writing, including the date on which you are leaving, to avoid a dispute over rent and the deposit.

snippets.description: Important advice when considering whether to end your fixed term tenancy
snippets.data:
If you leave without giving the correct amount of notice in writing or without an agreement with the landlord(s) then you will remain liable for the rent until the landlord ends the tenancy. This could be many months. You will also find it hard to rent again, as a new landlord is likely to want a reference from your old landlord.

You should think carefully before you try to end your tenancy. You should only try to end a tenancy when you have somewhere else to move to, otherwise you will become homeless. It is very hard to find housing when you are homeless. If you make yourself homelessness this will limit the duty that a council has to help you.

snippets.description: Ending your joint fixed term tenancy
snippets.data:
You do not have the right to end a fixed term tenancy as a fixed term tenancy binds both the tenants and the landlord(s), so it cannot be ended by either party until the fixed term ends, unless there is a 'break clause' in your tenancy agreement, which allows you to give notice and end your tenancy early.

The only way to end your tenancy is by reaching an agreement with the landlord (a process known as surrender). All joint tenants must agree. You should make sure that any agreement is recorded in writing, including the date on which you are leaving, to avoid a dispute over rent and the deposit.

snippets.description: Ending your sole tenancy - weekly periodic
snippets.data:
You must give your landlord notice in writing to end a periodic tenancy. This is called a 'notice to quit'. You must give the correct date for when your notice period ends, otherwise it will not be valid.

To work out the amount of notice you need to check your tenancy agreement. If it sets out the amount of notice you must give your landlord, follow what your agreement says. If your tenancy agreement doesn't set out a notice period then you must give your landlord at least 4 week's notice (28 days). Your notice must end on the first day or last day of your tenancy period. This is not always the date you pay your rent so check your agreement carefully.

If your tenancy started for example on a Monday:

  • the last day of the tenancy period will be on a Sunday
  • the first day of the next tenancy period be the following Monday

It's easier to calculate the final week's rent if you give notice to end on the last day of the tenancy period.

Your notice should include:

  • your name and address
  • your landlord's name and address
  • the date your notice period ends

You could also include a forwarding address for your landlord to return your tenancy deposit. If you deliver the letter to your landlord by hand, ask for a receipt. If you post it, use recorded delivery so you can prove it arrived. Don't send an email unless your tenancy says you can, otherwise your notice won't be valid.

The alternative way to end your tenancy is by reaching an agreement with the landlord (a process known as surrender). You should make sure that any agreement is recorded in writing, including the date on which you are leaving, to avoid a dispute over rent and the deposit.

snippets.description: Ending your joint tenancy - weekly periodic - no written agreement
snippets.data:
You must give your landlord notice in writing to end a periodic tenancy. This is called a 'notice to quit'. You must give the correct date for when your notice period ends, otherwise it will not be valid. If you are a joint tenant, notice can be given by one tenant.

You must give your landlord at least 4 week's notice (28 days).

Your notice must end on the first day or last day of your tenancy period. This will be the date on which your tenancy started (usually the day on which you moved in or had to pay the first week’s rent).

If your tenancy started for example on a Monday:

  • the last day of the tenancy period will be on a Sunday
  • the first day of the next tenancy period be the following Monday

It's easier to calculate the final week's rent if you give notice to end on the last day of the tenancy period.

Your notice should include:

  • your name and address
  • your landlord's name and address
  • the date your notice period ends

You could also include a forwarding address for your landlord to return your tenancy deposit.

If you deliver the letter to your landlord by hand, ask for a receipt. If you post it, use recorded delivery so you can prove it arrived.

Don't send an email unless your tenancy says you can, otherwise your notice won't be valid.

The alternative way to end your tenancy is by reaching an agreement with the landlord (a process known as surrender). You should make sure that any agreement is recorded in writing, including the date on which you are leaving, to avoid a dispute over rent and the deposit. If you are a joint tenant, then all tenants must agree with the landlord.

snippets.description: Ending your sole tenancy - fixed term
snippets.data:
You do not have the right to end a fixed term tenancy as a fixed term tenancy binds both the tenant and the landlord(s), so it cannot be ended by either party until the fixed term ends, unless there is a 'break clause' in your tenancy agreement, which allows you to give notice and end your tenancy early.

The only way to end your tenancy is by reaching an agreement with the landlord (a process known as surrender). You should make sure that any agreement is recorded in writing, including the date on which you are leaving, to avoid a dispute over rent and the deposit.

snippets.description: No gas cert before tenancy started - why your notice may be invalid
snippets.data: If your tenancy agreement started after the 1st of October 2015 and your landlord has failed to provide a gas safety certificate before your occupation of the property, the section 21 notice may be invalid. For more help, contact Lewisham Council Housing Team on 020 8314 3020.

snippets.description: No energy performance certificate   - why your notice is invalid
snippets.data: If your tenancy agreement started after the 1st of October 2015 and your landlord has failed to provide an energy performance certificate, the section 21 notice is invalid. For more help, contact Lewisham Council Housing Team on 020 8314 3020.

snippets.description: No gas cert within last 12 months  - why your notice is invalid
snippets.data: If your tenancy agreement started after the 1st of October 2015 and your landlord has failed to provide a gas safety certificate within the last 12 months, the section 21 notice is invalid. For more help, contact Lewisham Council Housing Team on 020 8314 3020.

snippets.description: No deposit information given  - why your notice is invalid
snippets.data: Your landlord must follow the tenancy deposit protection rules. They can't give you a valid section 21 notice before they give you required information about the tenancy deposit scheme used. For more help, contact Lewisham Council Housing Team on 020 8314 3020.

snippets.description: No "How to rent" booklet given  - why your notice is invalid
snippets.data:
If your tenancy agreement started after the 1st of October 2015 and your landlord has failed to provide you with a "How to rent" booklet, the section 21 notice is invalid. The current version of the booklet looks like this. Its important to note that the version served on the tenant needs to have been the version that was current at the start of the tenancy (or, if a fixed term tenancy was renewed, at the time of renewal). This may have been an earlier version. All the versions are available to see here.

For more help, contact Lewisham Council Housing Team on 020 8314 3020.

snippets.description: Deposit not protected within time frames - why your notice is invalid
snippets.data:
Your landlord can't give you a valid section 21 notice before they give you required information about the tenancy deposit scheme used. A section 21 notice is invalid if it was protected more than 30 days after your most recent contract started.

If your landlord breaks these rules, they can only serve a valid section 21 notice if they return your deposit first.

snippets.description: Improvement or emergency remedial notice - why your notice is invalid
snippets.data:
If you complain to the Council about the conditions in your home, the Council may serve an improvement or emergency remedial notice on your landlord. The purpose would be to ensure your landlord brings the property up to standard.

Your landlord cannot serve you with a section 21 notice within six months of the Council’s service of the improvement or emergency remedial notice. If he or she tries to do so, the section 21 notice will be invalid. This is to protect you from being evicted in retaliation for having made a complaint.

If your landlord is not carrying out the works that were required of them, you can contact Private Sector Housing Agency on 020 8314 3020 for more assistance.

snippets.description: Notice is older than 6 months - why your notice is invalid
snippets.data: The landlord must start court action with 6 months of issuing your notice. If they wait longer than this, the notice is invalid and they will have to issue a new notice. An exception would be if you have a periodic tenancy, and 2 months’ notice is required. If this is the case, the notice is only valid for 4 months after the date specified in Section 2.

snippets.description: Supply and demand of housing
snippets.data: Housing is in short supply. According to the housing campaign Shelter, 277,000 people are now homeless in England. The demand for social housing (council and housing association housing) is particularly high. Shelter estimates that 3.1 million people are in need of social housing and 1.15 million households on waiting lists, but only 290,000 social homes were made available last year – a difference of more than 800,000 homes.

snippets.description: Ending your joint tenancy - weekly periodic
snippets.data:
You must give your landlord notice in writing to end a periodic tenancy. This is called a 'notice to quit'. You must give the correct date for when your notice period ends, otherwise it will not be valid. Only one of the joint tenants needs to give the notice to quit.

To work out the amount of notice you need to check your tenancy agreement. If it sets out the amount of notice you must give your landlord, follow what your agreement says. If your tenancy agreement doesn't set out a notice period then you must give your landlord at least 4 week's notice (28 days). Your notice must end on the first day or last day of your tenancy period. This is not always the date you pay your rent so check your agreement carefully.

If your tenancy started for example on a Monday:

  • the last day of the tenancy period will be on a Sunday
  • the first day of the next tenancy period be the following Monday

It's easier to calculate the final week's rent if you give notice to end on the last day of the tenancy period.

Your notice should include:

  • your name and address
  • your landlord's name and address
  • the date your notice period ends

You could also include a forwarding address for your landlord to return your tenancy deposit. If you deliver the letter to your landlord by hand, ask for a receipt. If you post it, use recorded delivery so you can prove it arrived. Don't send an email unless your tenancy says you can, otherwise your notice won't be valid.

The alternative way to end your tenancy is by reaching an agreement with the landlord (a process known as surrender). You should make sure that any agreement is recorded in writing, including the date on which you are leaving, to avoid a dispute over rent and the deposit.

Your notice should include:

  • your landlord's name and address
  • the date your notice period ends

You could also include a forwarding address for your landlord to return your tenancy deposit. If you deliver the letter to your landlord by hand, ask for a receipt. If you post it, use recorded delivery so you can prove it arrived. Don't send an email unless your tenancy says you can, otherwise your notice won't be valid.

The alternative way to end your tenancy is by reaching an agreement with the landlord (a process known as surrender). You should make sure that any agreement is recorded in writing, including the date on which you are leaving, to avoid a dispute over rent and the deposit.

snippets.description: Tenancy deposit - check if your deposit is protected
snippets.data:
You can check if the deposit is protected on the following websites:

  • mydeposits
  • Tenancy Deposit Scheme (TDS)
  • Deposit Protection Service (DPS)

If you paid a deposit on or after 6 April 2007 then it must be protected (in many circumstances a deposit paid before 6 April 2007 must also be protected). If your deposit is not protected then you should get advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453 or Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444.

snippets.description: Tenancy deposit - raise a dispute with the Tenancy Deposit Scheme (TDS)
snippets.data:
The first step is to ask your landlord or their agent for the deposit to be returned in full. If you have done this put the request in writing and tell your landlord that unless it is returned within 7 days you will raise a dispute. If the landlord still refuses to return all of your deposit then you can raise a dispute through the Tenancy Deposit Scheme website.

You should do so within 3 months of leaving the property. You will need to upload your evidence. This should include the request for the return of the deposit, tenancy agreement, relevant photos, check in/out reports or rent statements, any witness statements. This will then be considered by an adjudicator who will make a decision.

snippets.description: Tenancy deposit - Raise a dispute with mydeposits
snippets.data:
The first step is to ask your landlord or their agent for the deposit to be returned in full. If you have done this put the request in writing and tell your landlord that unless it is returned within 7 days you will raise a dispute. If the landlord still refuses to return all of your deposit then you can raise a dispute through the mydeposits website.

You should do so within 3 months of leaving the property. You will need to upload your evidence. This should include the request for the return of the deposit, tenancy agreement, relevant photos, check in/out reports or rent statements, any witness statements. This will then be considered by an adjudicator who will make a decision.

snippets.description: Tenancy deposit - tenancy has not ended yet
snippets.data: Your landlord is not required to return your deposit until the tenancy has ended and you have returned the keys.

snippets.description: Tenancy deposits - Issue a small claim in the county court to get deposit back
snippets.data: As you are not an assured shorthold tenant your landlord is not required to protect your deposit. You should write to your landlord and ask them to return the deposit within 14 days. If they do not do so, then you can issue a small claim in the county court for the amount of the deposit. Apply to the county court for money you are owed.

snippets.description: Tenancy deposits - take court action to get your deposit back and claim compensation
snippets.data:
The landlord had to protect the deposit. If they haven’t done so you can take court action to get your deposit back and claim compensation. You need to take the following steps:

  • Check if the deposit is protected on the following websites:
    mydeposits
    Tenancy Deposit Scheme (TDS)
    Deposit Protection Service (DPS)
    If it is not protected, then
  • Send your landlord a formal 'letter before action'. You should give the landlord 14 days to return the deposit. Inform them that if they do not do so you will issue a court claim for the amount of the deposit and compensation of three times the deposit. Shelter has a template letter that you can use.
  • If you paid the deposit to an agent then you should also send the letter to the agent and issue any court proceedings against both the landlord and the agent
  • Apply to court using Form N208 (following included guidance). You will have to pay the court fee of £308 to start your claim, but can claim it back from your landlord if you win your case. You lose the court fee if you don't win. You can apply for a fee reduction or exemption if you claim certain benefits or have a low income:

If you need help with this process then you should contact Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453 or Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444.

snippets.description: Tenancy deposits - tenancy started before 6th of April 2007
snippets.data: Where a deposit was paid in respect of a fixed-term tenancy that became a statutory periodic tenancy before 6 April 2007, and has never been renewed since, the landlord did not have to protect the deposit. You should get advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453 or Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444 if your tenancy started before 6 April 2007.

snippets.description: Steps to take when issued with possession proceedings - council tenant
snippets.data:
You should have received in the court papers a completed Claim Form (Form N5), Particulars of Claim (Form N119) Guidance Notes and a blank Defence Form (Form N11R).

Step 1: Contact your housing, rent or income officer

Contact the person at the Council offices who has been dealing with you (this could be a housing officer, rent or income officer). If you have benefit, debt or other problems then ask them for help. Try to reach an agreement that the possession proceedings be adjourned on terms that you pay the rent and an affordable amount towards the arrears each week. If the case is about anti-social behaviour, then try to reach an agreement about your behaviour in the future.

Step 2: Complete the Defence Form

If possible, you should complete and send off the Defence Form within 14 days of receiving the court documents, but if you miss this deadline you should still complete the Defence Form. If necessary, you can take it with you to the hearing. The questions in the Defence Form follow the numbered paragraphs in the Particulars of Claim (Form N119). They ask a series of questions which require mainly yes or no answers. If you want to provide more information, then you can do so in the boxes or at paragraph 29. You can continue on another sheet if necessary and attach any evidence. Any attachments should be marked with the Claim Number, which is found on the top right-hand side of the Claim Form.

If the Particulars of Claim at paragraph 4 state that possession is claimed on Ground 1 (rent arrears) then the judge will have to consider whether it is reasonable to grant an order for possession at all. If it is reasonable, they will consider whether any order should be postponed or suspended, provided you comply with terms for repayment of the arrears in instalments, on top of the rent. In paragraph 29 of the Defence Form you need to set out in full your circumstances, why you got into rent arrears, the circumstances of anyone who lives with you (including their ages, disabilities or health problems), and why you can now pay the rent. You should make an offer to pay the rent arrears in affordable instalments. You can continue on another sheet if necessary and attach any evidence. Any attachments should be marked with the Claim Number, which is found on the top right-hand side of the Claim Form.

If the Particulars of Claim at paragraph 4 state that possession is claimed on other Grounds than Ground 1 then you should get advice (see Step 3).

The completed Defence Form should be sent to the court and to the council (these addresses are on the Claim Form).

If you need help in completing the Defence Form, then get advice (see Step 3)

Step 3: Get advice

If possible you should get advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453, Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444 or a solicitor. Legal Aid is available for advice about possession proceedings.

Step 4: Attend the hearing

You must attend the hearing. You should do this even if you have not done anything else. This is your chance to explain things to the judge. If you do not go, then the judge will make the decision in your absence. The hearing will be held in private. There will be a representative from the council there. You might be able to reach an agreement. You should arrive 30 minutes before the hearing time. Most county courts have duty solicitors, who will provide advice and representation free of charge. In the hearing, you will have an opportunity to explain your circumstances. You should speak clearly, but don’t interrupt anyone else when they are speaking. Be polite. Don't argue with the judge or the representative of the landlord. You can call the judge ‘Sir’ or ‘Madam’. You can read more about going to civil court without a lawyer here.

snippets.description: Steps to take when issued with standard possession proceedings - housing association tenant
snippets.data:

You should contact your housing, rent or income officer and explain your circumstances. If you have benefit, debt or other problems then ask them for help.
