Any attachments should be marked with the Claim Number, which is found on the top right-hand side of the Claim Form.

If the Particulars of Claim at paragraph 4 state that possession is claimed on other Grounds than 8, 10 or 11 then you should get advice (see Step 3).

The completed Defence Form should be sent to the court and to the landlord or the landlord’s representative (these addresses are on the Claim Form).

If you need help in completing the Defence Form, then get advice (see Step 3)

Step 3: Get advice

If possible you should get advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453, Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444 or a solicitor. Legal Aid is available for advice about possession proceedings.

Step 4: Attend the hearing

You must attend the hearing. You should do this even if you have not done anything else. This is your chance to explain things to the judge. If you do not go, then the judge will make the decision in your absence. The hearing will be held in private. There will be a representative from your housing association there. You might be able to reach an agreement. You should arrive 30 minutes before the hearing time. Most county courts have duty solicitors, who will provide advice and representation free of charge. In the hearing, you will have an opportunity to explain your circumstances. You should speak clearly, but don’t interrupt anyone else when they are speaking. Be polite. Don't argue with the judge or the representative of the landlord. You can call the judge ‘Sir’ or ‘Madam’. You can read more about going to civil court without a lawyer here.

snippets.description: Steps to take when issued with accelerated possession proceedings - housing association tenant
snippets.data:
You should have received in the court papers a completed Claim Form (Form N5B), Guidance Notes and a blank Defence Form (Form N11B).

Step 1: Contact your housing officer

You should contact your housing officer and find out why they are seeking to evict you. You should then explain your circumstances and try to reach an agreement to avoid being evicted.

Step 2: Complete the Defence Form

If possible, you should complete and send off the Defence Form within 14 days of receiving the court documents, but if you miss this deadline you should still complete the Defence Form. The questions in the Defence Form follow the numbered paragraphs in the Claim Form (Form N5B). They ask a series of questions which require mainly yes or no answers. If you want to provide more information, then you can do so in the boxes or on page 5. You can continue on another sheet if necessary and attach any evidence. Any attachments should be marked with the Claim Number, which is found on the top right-hand side of the Claim Form.

If you are seeking more time because the eviction will cause you exceptional hardship, then you must complete question 14 and set out why. The maximum time that the court can postpone possession is 6 weeks (42 days).

The completed Defence Form should be sent to the court and to the landlord or the landlord’s representative (these addresses are on the Claim Form).

If you need help in completing the Defence Form, then get advice (see Step 3)

Step 3: Get advice

If possible you should get advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453, Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444 or a solicitor. Legal Aid is available for advice about possession proceedings.

Step 4: Attend the hearing if there is one

A judge will consider the Claim Form and if you have sent one in, your Defence. The judge will then decide whether a hearing is needed. The judge may make a decision on the papers without a hearing.

If there is a hearing, then you must attend the hearing. You should do this even if you have not done anything else. This is your chance to explain things to the judge. If you do not go, then the judge will make the decision in your absence. The hearing will be held in private. There will be a representative from your housing association there. You should arrive 30 minutes before the hearing time. Most county courts have duty solicitors, who will provide advice and representation free of charge. In the hearing, you will have an opportunity to explain your circumstances. You should speak clearly, but don’t interrupt anyone else when they are speaking. Be polite. Don't argue with the judge or the representative of the landlord. You can call the judge ‘Sir’ or ‘Madam’. You can read more about going to civil court without a lawyer here.

snippets.description: Steps to take when housing association tenant receives notice of eviction
snippets.data:
You may be able to make an application to the Court to stop the eviction. You will need to act quickly, as an application must be made before the date and time on the notice of eviction. You will need a copy of the possession order. You will also need to contact the court to arrange to issue the application, as court offices are not open to the public at all times. You should follow the steps set out here.

Step 1: Look at the possession order

You need to look at the possession order, which may have been made some time ago. If you do not have a copy of the possession order then you should ask your housing, rent or income officer for a copy, but if there is not time you may need to make the application before you can get a copy.

The court cannot suspend the eviction (technically the warrant) if the possession order was made on mandatory grounds. Read the possession order. If it says that the order was made on a mandatory ground or under Ground 8 or Section 21 then the court cannot suspend the eviction. You should get advice (Step 4). However, if the possession order does not say that it was on a mandatory ground or under Ground 8 or Section 21 then the court does have the power to suspend the eviction. You should follow the other steps set out here.

Step 2: Contact your housing, rent or income officer if there is time

If there is time then you should contact your housing, rent or income officer and explain your circumstances. If you have benefit, debt or other problems then ask them for help. Try to reach an agreement that the eviction be adjourned on terms that you pay the rent and an affordable amount towards the arrears each week. If the case is about anti-social behaviour, then try to reachan agreement about your behaviour in the future. If there is not time to contact your housing association, then move to step 3.

Step 3: Make an application to court

You make the application using form N244. You should read the guidance notes. At question 10 you should set out all the reasons why the eviction should be suspended and set out in full your circumstances, why you breached the possession order, the circumstances of anyone who lives with you (including their ages, disabilities or health problems), and why you can now pay the rent. You should make an offer to pay the rent arrears in affordable instalments. You can continue on another sheet if necessary and attach any evidence. Any attachments should be marked with the Claim Number, which you should have entered on the top right hand side of the application (and which can be found on the possession order and notice of eviction).

If the order for possession was made on grounds other than rent arrears, then you should get advice (see Step 4).

The completed application must be issued in court. To do this you will need to contact the court. You can find the court details here. Make sure that the application is issued by the court before the date and time of the eviction. If you need help in completing the application to the court, then get advice (see Step 4).

There is a fee of £50. If you are low waged or on a qualifying benefit then you should be fee exempt. You can make an application for fee exemption online here.

Step 4: Get advice

If possible you should get advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453, Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444 or a solicitor.

Legal Aid is available for advice about possession proceedings.

However if you cannot get advice before the date and time of the eviction then you should issue the application on your own.

Step 5: Attend the hearing

When an application is issued you will be given a hearing date and time. You must attend the hearing. This is your chance to explain things to the judge. If you do not go, then the judge will make the decision in your absence. The hearing will be held in private. There will be a representative from your housing association will be there. You might be able to reach an agreement. You should arrive 30 minutes before the hearing time. There may be a duty solicitor who may be able to provide advice and representation free of charge. In the hearing, you will have an opportunity to explain your circumstances. You should speak clearly, but don’t interrupt anyone else when they are speaking. Be polite. Don't argue with the judge or the representative of the landlord. You can call the judge ‘Sir’ or ‘Madam’. You can read more about going to civil court without a lawyer here.

snippets.description: Eviction - application for reinstatement
snippets.data:
There are only limited grounds on which an application for reinstatement can be made. You will need to act quickly, as any delay will reduce your chance of being successful. You should urgently get advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453, Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444 or a solicitor.

Legal Aid is available for advice about reinstatement.

snippets.description: Steps to take when issued with possession proceedings - homeowner
snippets.data:
If the court case has been issued by the mortgage company due to mortgage arrears, then please follow the advice here. If this is a claim for forfeiture, then you should get legal advice (see Step 3 below).

You should have received in the court papers a completed Claim Form (Form N5), Particulars of Claim (Form N120) Guidance Notes and a blank Defence Form (Form N11M).

Step 1: Contact your lender

You should contact your lender and explain your circumstances. Try to reach an agreement that the possession proceedings be adjourned on terms that you pay the mortgage and an affordable amount towards the arrears each week. To work out what you should offer divide the arrears by the number of months remaining on the mortgage. This figure will be the absolute minimum you should offer towards the mortgage arrears each month, so offer more if you can afford to do so.

Step 2: Complete the Defence Form.

If possible, you should complete and send off the Defence Form within 14 days of receiving the court documents, but if you miss this deadline you should still complete the Defence Form. If necessary, you can take it with you to the hearing. The questions in the Defence Form follow the numbered paragraphs in the Particulars of Claim (Form N120). They ask a series of questions which require mainly yes or no answers, but you will need financial information. If you want to provide more information, then you can do so in the boxes or at paragraph 27. You can continue on another sheet if necessary and attach any evidence. Any attachments should be marked with the Claim Number, which is found on the top right-hand side of the Claim Form.

The judge will have to consider whether it is reasonable to grant an order for possession at all. If it is reasonable, they will consider whether any order should be postponed or suspended, provided you comply with terms for repayment of the mortgage arrears in instalments. In paragraph 27 of the Defence Form you need to set out in full your circumstances, why you got into rent arrears, the circumstances of anyone who lives with you (including their ages, disabilities or health problems), and why you can now pay the mortgage. You should make an offer to pay the mortgage arrears in affordable instalments (see Step 1 above). You can continue on another sheet if necessary and attach any evidence. Any attachments should be marked with the Claim Number, which is found on the top right-hand side of the Claim Form.

The completed Defence Form should be sent to the court and to the lender or the lender’s representative (these addresses are on the Claim Form).

If you need help in completing the Defence Form, then get advice (see Step 3)

Step 3: Get advice

If possible you should get advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453, Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444 or a solicitor. Or call the Civil Legal Advice helpline 0345 345 4 345

Legal Aid is available for advice about possession proceedings as a debt matter.

Step 4: Attend the hearing

You must attend the hearing. You should do this even if you have not done anything else. This is your chance to explain things to the judge. If you do not go, then the judge will make the decision in your absence. The hearing will be held in private. A representative of your lender will be there. You might be able to reach an agreement. You should arrive 30 minutes before the hearing time. Most county courts have duty solicitors, who will provide advice and representation free of charge. In the hearing, you will have an opportunity to explain your circumstances. You should speak clearly, but don’t interrupt anyone else when they are speaking. Be polite. Don't argue with the judge or the representative of the landlord. You can call the judge ‘Sir’ or ‘Madam’. You can read more about going to civil court without a lawyer here.

snippets.description: Steps to take when council tenant receives notice of eviction
snippets.data:
You can and should make an application to the court to stop the eviction. The court can suspend the eviction (technically the warrant) on terms. You will need to act quickly, as the application must be made before the date and time on the notice of eviction. You will also need to contact the court to arrange to issue the application, as court offices are not open to the public at all times. You should follow the steps set out here.

Step 1: Contact your housing, rent or income officer if there is time

If there is time then you should contact your housing, rent or income officer and explain your circumstances. If you have benefit, debt or other problems then ask them for help. Try to reach an agreement that the eviction be adjourned on terms that you pay the rent and an affordable amount towards the arrears each week. If the case is about anti-social behaviour, then try to reach an agreement about your behaviour in the future. If there is not the time to contact the council then move to step 2.

Step 2: Make an application to the court

You make the application using form N244. You should read the guidance notes. At question 10 you should set out all the reasons why the eviction should be suspended and set out in full your circumstances, why you breached the possession order, the circumstances of anyone who lives with you (including their ages, disabilities or health problems), and why you can now pay the rent. You should make an offer to pay the rent arrears in affordable instalments. You can continue on another sheet if necessary and attach any evidence. Any attachments should be marked with the Claim Number, which you should have entered on the top right-hand side of the application (and which can be found on the possession order and notice of eviction). If the order for possession was made on grounds other than rent arrears, then you should get advice (see Step 3).

The completed application must be issued in court. To do this you will need to contact the court. You can find the court details here. Make sure that the application is issued by the court before the date and time of the eviction. If you need help in completing the application to the court, then get advice (see Step 3).

There is a fee of £50. If you are low waged or on a qualifying benefit then you should be fee exempt. You can make an application for fee exemption online here.

Step 3: Get advice

If possible you should get advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453, Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444 or a solicitor. Or call the Civil Legal Advice helpline 0345 345 4 345.

Legal Aid is available for advice about possession proceedings.

However if you cannot get advice before the date and time of the eviction then you should issue the application on your own.

Step 4: Attend the hearing

When an application is issued you will be given a hearing date and time. You must attend the hearing. This is your chance to explain things to the judge. If you do not go, then the judge will make the decision in your absence. The hearing will be held in private. There will be a representative from the council there. You might be able to reach an agreement. You should arrive 30 minutes before the hearing time. There may be a duty solicitor who may be able to provide advice and representation free of charge. In the hearing, you will have an opportunity to explain your circumstances. You should speak clearly, but don’t interrupt anyone else when they are speaking. Be polite. Don't argue with the judge or the representative of the landlord. You can call the judge ‘Sir’ or ‘Madam’. You can read more about going to civil court without a lawyer here.

snippets.description: Steps to take when private tenant receives notice of eviction
snippets.data:
You may be able to make an application to the Court to stop the eviction. You will need to act quickly, as an application must be made before the date and time on the notice of eviction. You will need a copy of the possession order. You will also need to contact the court to arrange to issue the application, as court offices are not open to the public at all times. You should follow the steps set out here.

Step 1: Look at the possession order

You need to look at the possession order, which may have been made some time ago. If you do not have a copy of the possession order then you should ask your landlord or the court for a copy, but if there is not time you may need to make the application before you can get a copy.

The court cannot suspend the eviction (technically the warrant) if the possession order was made on mandatory grounds. Read the possession order. If it says that the order was made on a mandatory ground or under Ground 8 or Section 21 then the court cannot suspend the eviction. You should get advice (Step 4). However, if the possession order does not say that it was on a mandatory ground or under Ground 8 or Section 21 then the court does have the power to suspend the eviction. You should follow the other steps set out here.

Step 2: Contact your landlord if there is time

If there is time then you should contact your landlord and explain your circumstances. Try to reach an agreement that the eviction be adjourned on terms that you pay the rent and an affordable amount towards the arrears each week. If the case is about anti-social behaviour, then try to reach an agreement about your behaviour in the future. If there is not the time to contact your landlord, then move to step 3.

Step 3: Make an application to court

You make the application using form N244. You should read the guidance notes. At question 10 you should set out all the reasons why the eviction should be suspended and set out in full your circumstances, why you breached the possession order, the circumstances of anyone who lives with you (including their ages, disabilities or health problems), and why you can now pay the rent. You should make an offer to pay the rent arrears in affordable instalments. You can continue on another sheet if necessary and attach any evidence. Any attachments should be marked with the Claim Number, which you should have entered on the top right-hand side of the application (and which can be found on the possession order and notice of eviction).

If the order for possession was made on grounds other than rent arrears, then you should get advice (see Step 4).

The completed application must be issued in court. To do this you will need to contact the court. You can find the court details here. Make sure that the application is issued by the court before the date and time of the eviction. If you need help in completing the application to the court, then get advice (see Step 4).

There is a fee of £50. If you are low waged or on a qualifying benefit then you should be fee exempt. You can make an application for fee exemption online here.

Step 4: Get advice

If possible you should get advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453, Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444 or a solicitor.

Legal Aid is available for advice about possession proceedings.

However if you cannot get advice before the date and time of the eviction then you should issue the application on your own.

Step 5: Attend the hearing

When an application is issued you will be given a hearing date and time. You must attend the hearing. This is your chance to explain things to the judge. If you do not go, then the judge will make the decision in your absence. The hearing will be held in private. Your landlord or their representative will be there. You might be able to reach an agreement. You should arrive 30 minutes before the hearing time. There may be a duty solicitor who may be able to provide advice and representation free of charge. In the hearing, you will have an opportunity to explain your circumstances. You should speak clearly, but don’t interrupt anyone else when they are speaking. Be polite. Don't argue with the judge or the representative of the landlord. You can call the judge ‘Sir’ or ‘Madam’. You can read more about going to civil court without a lawyer here.

snippets.description: Eviction - illegal eviction
snippets.data:
In most cases, it is unlawful for a landlord or lender to evict someone without first obtaining a court possession order and then enforcing this by the court bailiffs. The main exceptions are where you have a resident landlord or where you were put in interim accommodation pending a decision on your homelessness application, but there are other exceptions. You may be able to obtain an injunction to get back into your home, but you will need to act quickly, as any delay will reduce your chance of being successful. You should urgently get advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453, Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444 or a solicitor.

Legal Aid is available for advice about illegal eviction.

snippets.description: Eviction process for a homeowner explained
snippets.data:
Step 1: Warning letters

Before issuing a claim in the county court, the lender will write to you about your mortgage arrears. This is an opportunity to pay any mortgage arrears or come to an agreement with your lender. They should give you a reasonable period of time to clear any arrears. To work out what you should offer, divide the arrears by the number of months remaining on the mortgage. This figure will be the absolute minimum you should offer towards the mortgage arrears each month, so offer more if you can afford to do so. They key thing is - do not ignore the letters, but contact your lender and see what is required to stop them from taking further action.

You should also get advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453, Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444 or a solicitor. Or Call the Civil Legal Advice helpline 0345 345 4 345

Legal Aid is available for advice about mortgage possession proceedings as a debt matter.

Step 2: A claim is issued in the county court

In most cases, a lender must obtain a court possession order. There will then be a court hearing. You can file a defence to the claim for possession using the form that is delivered with the possession claim. You should also attend the hearing as this is your chance to explain your circumstances to the judge.

The judge will make a decision at the hearing. The judge has discretion about whether to make a possession order at all and, if they do, to suspend it on terms. Therefore it is always important to send off the defence and attend any hearing.

Step 3: Eviction by court bailiffs

Even where a possession order is granted, it can only be enforced by court bailiffs or sometimes by High Court Sheriffs. If the bailiffs are attending you will receive a notice of eviction telling you the date and time. If the matter is transferred to the High Court then you should be notified of this.

You can make an application to suspend the eviction.

snippets.description: Information on the legal test and duties that councils have to the homeless
snippets.data:
There are a number of legal tests and duties that we have to the homeless. These are found in the main legislation and regulations. We must also consider and generally follow the homelessness code of guidance. There is additional guidance for 16 and 17 year olds. We have produced a strategy setting out how we will assist the homeless.


Main legislation

Housing Act 1996, Part 7

Regulations

The Allocation of Housing and Homelessness (Eligibility) (England) Regulations 2006

The Homelessness (Priority Need for Accommodation) (England) Order 2002

The Homelessness (Decisions on Referrals) Order 1998

The Homelessness (Suitability of Accommodation) (England) Order 2003

The Homelessness (Suitability of Accommodation) (England) Order 2012

The Homelessness (Review Procedure etc.) Regulations 2018


Other

Homelessness Code of Guidance

Provision of accommodation for 16 and 17 year olds who may be homeless and/or require accommodation

Procedures for referrals of homeless applicants to another local authority

Our Homelessness Strategy is available to view at lewisham.gov.uk/-/media/files/imported/housingstrategy2015.ashx

snippets.description: Explained: Threatened with homelessness
snippets.data:
A person is threatened with homelessness if it is likely that they will become homeless within 56 days.

A person is also threatened with homelessness if:

  • they have been given a valid section 21 notice in respect of their only accommodation, and
  • the notice is due to expire within 56 days.

snippets.description: Explained: Homeless
snippets.data:
There are several ways in which a person can is considered to be homeless in law:

  • no accommodation available in the UK or abroad
  • no legal right to occupy any accommodation
  • where households are split and there is no accommodation and available for whole household
  • unreasonable to continue to occupy accommodation
  • violence from any person
  • unable to secure entry to the accommodation
  • living in a moveable structure but no place to put and live in it.

snippets.description: Eviction process for a tenant explained
snippets.data:
Step 1: Notice

The first stage in the eviction process is that the landlord must serve a valid notice on you. Different kinds of tenancies require different kinds of notice and different notice periods. This can be complex. The purpose of most notices is twofold: to allow you to remedy any breach and as the start of the eviction process if you do not. Therefore this is an opportunity to pay any rent arrears, modify any behaviour and come to an agreement with your landlord. They key thing is - do not ignore the notice, but contact your landlord and see what is required to get the notice withdrawn.

You should also get advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453, Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444 or a solicitor.

Step 2: A claim is issued in the county court

In most cases, a landlord must obtain a court possession order. The main exceptions are where you have a resident landlord or where you were put in interim accommodation pending a decision on your homelessness application, but there are other exceptions. If a possession order is not required then the landlord could change the locks when you are out, but they cannot use force to evict you or interfere with your belongings.

In most cases there must be a court hearing. The exception is eviction using Section 21 and the accelerated possession procedure. You can file a defence to the claim for possession using the form that is delivered with the possession claim. If there is a hearing, then you should also attend the hearing as this is your chance to explain your circumstances to the judge.

The judge will make a decision either at the court hearing, or if it is an accelerated possession claim, by looking at the papers. The judge will make a possession order if he or she is satisfied with the circumstances of the claim. The usual time between the judge’s decision and the possession date is 14 days, but this can be extended to 42 days. However, in many cases the judge has a discretion about whether to make a possession order at all. If they do decide to make a possession order, they can suspend it, provided you comply with terms that they lay down. Therefore it is always important to send off the defence and attend any hearing.

Step 3: Eviction by court bailiffs

Even where a possession order is granted, it can only be enforced by court bailiffs or sometimes by High Court Sheriffs. If the bailiffs are attending you will receive a notice of eviction telling you the date and time. If the matter is transferred to the High Court then you should be notified of this.

You may be able to suspend the eviction. This will depend on whether the possession order is made on mandatory or discretionary grounds. It will tell you this on the possession order. The court cannot suspend the eviction if the possession order was made on mandatory grounds.

snippets.description: Explained: Eligibility
snippets.data:
The eligibility rules are different for UK/EEA nationals and non-UK/EEA nationals (persons subject to immigration control).

The following are likely to be eligible:

UK Nationals

  • People who are habitually resident in the common travel area (UK, the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man and the Republic of Ireland)

Find out about the habitual residence test.

EEA Nationals

  • Workers
  • Self-employed persons
  • Retired or incapacitated workers and self-employed people.
  • Family of workers and self-employed
  • People with five years' residence in the UK

Persons Subject to Immigration Control

  • Refugees (but not asylum seekers)
  • People with exceptional leave to enter or remain
  • People with indefinite leave to remain
  • People granted humanitarian protection
  • Relevant Afghan citizens
  • People granted leave under Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights
  • Where leave is granted to unaccompanied refugee children relocated to the UK
  • People with 'Calais leave' under paragraph 252J immigration rules

snippets.description: Explained: Homelessness Due to Violence
snippets.data:
Violence means violence from another person or threats of violence from another person which are likely to be carried out. Violence (whether domestic or other violence) should be interpreted in a broad way to include not just physical violence, but also threatening or intimidating behaviour.

Domestic violence includes threatening behaviour, violence or abuse, whether it be psychological, physical, sexual, financial or emotional.

If you are in immediate danger of violence, call 999. 

If you are experiencing domestic violence and need to speak to someone about this, we would advise you to contact the Athena Service on 0800 112 4052 or email lewishamvawg@refuge.org.uk. Alternatively, you can contact the 24-Hour National Domestic Abuse Helpline on their freephone number: 0808 2000 247.

snippets.description: Eviction process - other
snippets.data:
As you are not a tenant or a home owner then you should get advice about what, if any, security of tenure you have and what rights you have.

You can get advice from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453, Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444 or a solicitor.

snippets.description: Help available from council: Domestic abuse
snippets.data:
Domestic abuse includes threatening behaviour, violence or abuse, whether it be psychological, physical, sexual, financial or emotional.

We have a legal duty to prevent and relieve homelessness. Firstly we need to check if you are eligible for assistance. If you are eligible for assistance, or if we cannot decide whether you are, we will arrange for a safe place for you and your household to stay. We will apply the legal test of homelessness due to violence.

We may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council, as long as you would not be at risk of violence. If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally, we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer-term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

You may also want to seek specialist advice and support about your situation from Athena service, run by Refuge on 0800 112 4052 or email lewishamvawg@refuge.org.uk . There are also national advice and support organisations:

Women’s Aid: Freephone 24hr National Domestic Violence Helpline: 0808 2000 247
Men's Advice Line: Monday – Friday 9am-5pm on freephone 0808 801 0327

snippets.description: Help available from the council: I have nowhere to stay tonight
snippets.data:
We have a legal duty to prevent homelessness. Firstly we need to check if you are eligible for assistance. If you are eligible for assistance, we will consider where you stayed last night, whether this is suitable accommodation and whether you can go back there and stay. We will also explore other options to stay with family or friend with you.

If we cannot prevent your homelessness then we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council. If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally, we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer-term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

You can come to our Housing Contact Centre at Laurence House, 1 Catford Road, SE6 4RU, 10am-4pm, Monday to Friday. 

Alternatively you can call out council call centre on 020 8314 3020.

snippets.description: Help available from the council: I can't afford to live in my home
snippets.data:
We have a legal duty to prevent homelessness. Firstly we will consider whether your home is affordable. This will involve looking at your income and outgoings and any other debts that you have. We may refer you for debt and money management advice with Advice Lewisham. If your home is not affordable then we need to check if you are eligible for assistance.

If you are eligible for assistance, we will consider whether your home can be made affordable by increasing your income and/or negotiating with your landlord. We may check to see whether you are getting all the benefits that you are entitled too or whether there are other sources of money, such as a discretionary housing payment.

If we cannot prevent your homelessness then we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council. If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally we have to do this for a period of 56 days.

In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer-term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

You can come to our Housing Contact Centre at Laurence House, 1 Catford Road, SE6 4RU, 10am-4pm, Monday to Friday. 

Alternatively you can call our council call centre on 020 8314 3020.

snippets.description: Help available from the council: My home is being repossessed by a mortgage lender
snippets.data:
We have a legal duty to prevent homelessness. We need to check if you are eligible for assistance. If you are eligible for assistance, we will negotiate with your lender to try and keep you in your home and protect your rights to live there. We may check to see whether you are getting all the benefits that you are entitled too or whether there are other sources of money, such as payment protection insurance or from the DWP.

If we cannot prevent your homelessness and you become homeless then we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council. If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

snippets.description: Make contact with us
snippets.data: If you have not already done so, you should make contact with the Lewisham Council Housing Team on 020 8314 3020.

snippets.description: Make contact with us urgently
snippets.data: Don't delay. If you have not already done so, you should make contact with the Lewisham Council Housing Team on 020 8314 3020. Do it now.

snippets.description: Explained: The Prevention Duty
snippets.data:
The prevention duty places a duty on the council to work with people who are threatened with homelessness within 56 days to help prevent them from becoming homelessness. In doing so the council must consider the Personalised Housing Plan. The first option to be explored with the applicant should be enabling them to remain in their current home, where suitable. Where this is not possible, the focus should be on helping to secure alternative accommodation that the applicant can move into in a planned way. This will often involve taking steps to extend an applicant’s stay in their existing accommodation until they can move.

When the duty comes to an end the council must notify an applicant and explain the reason.

snippets.description: Explained: Assessment
snippets.data:
The assessment must include:

  • the circumstances that have caused a person to be homeless or threatened with homelessness;
  • the persons housing needs, and what accommodation would be suitable for them, their household and anybody who might reasonably be expected to live with them; and,
  • the support that would be necessary for them, and anybody who will be living with them, to have and sustain suitable accommodation.

The assessment feeds into the personalised housing plan.

snippets.description: Explained: Personalised Housing Plan
snippets.data:
A personalised housing plan (PHP) must be drawn up based on the housing needs assessment. A PHP must contain:

  • any steps the applicant is to be required to take to find and retain accommodation for their household
  • the steps the council will take to assist the applicant in finding and retaining accommodation

It may also include steps that the council recommends the applicant takes, but they are not required to take.

The PHP should be agreed with the applicant and the council must keep the required steps under review. An assessment must be carried out and a PHP drawn up within a reasonable period of time. An applicant must co-operate with the steps set put in the PHP and there are potential implications for any duty owed where an applicant deliberately and unreasonably refuses to co-operate.

snippets.description: Explained: The Relief Duty
snippets.data:
The relief duty requires councils to help people who are homeless to secure accommodation. In doing so the council must consider the Personalised Housing Plan. The council will look at the range of options available.

When the duty comes to an end the council must notify an applicant and explain the reason (unless the council accepts the main housing duty).

snippets.description: Explained: Intentionally Homeless
snippets.data:
Consideration of whether a person is intentionally homeless requires the council to look at how the last settled accommodation was lost. There are two ways a person may be intentionally homeless.

The first has three parts, all of which must be satisfied:

  • the applicant must deliberately have done, or failed to do, something in consequence of which they have ceased to occupy accommodation which was available to them
  • it must have been reasonable for the applicant to continue to occupy the accommodation
  • the applicant must have been aware of all the relevant facts before deliberately taking or failing to take the actions. An act or omission in good faith on the part of a person unaware of a relevant fact should not be treated as deliberate.

The second has four parts, all of which must be satisfied:

  • the applicant enters into an arrangement under which they are required to cease to occupy accommodation
  • it must have been reasonable for the applicant to have continued to occupy the accommodation
  • the purpose of the arrangement is to enable the applicant to become entitled to assistance as a homeless person
  • there is no other good reason why s/he is homeless or threatened with homelessness.

This is about collusion between the applicant and the person who was accommodating them.

Where the council decides that an applicant is intentionally homeless it will secure that suitable accommodation is available for such a period as the clouncil considers will give the applicant a reasonable opportunity to secure other accommodation and provide advice and assistance, based on the assessment of the applicant's needs, to help them secure somewhere to live.

In accordance with the Council’s procedure in cases of intentionally homeless families, a referral will be made to the Children and Families Social Services Department local to you. A copy of your s184 Intentionally Homeless decision letter will be enclosed with the referral to ensure the Social Services Department has been notified of this decision and that you are being asked to leave your current accommodation.

snippets.description: Explained: Priority Need
snippets.data:
These following must be accepted as having a priority need for accommodation:

  • pregnant women, or any person who resides with a pregnant woman
  • households with whom dependent children reside or might reasonably be expected to reside
  • 16- and 17-year-olds, provided they are not a 'relevant child' (relevant children remain the responsibility of social services) or a child in need to whom a local authority owes a duty under section 20 of the Children Act 1989
  • 18- to 20-year olds (other than 'relevant students'), who at any time after reaching the age of sixteen, but while still under eighteen' were, but are no longer, looked after, accommodated or fostered
  • any person who has lost their home as a result of an emergency such as flood, fire or other disaster.

The following groups will be accepted as in priority need provided that the council is satisfied that they are vulnerable.

  • old age, mental illness or disability, physical disability or other special reason, or someone who lives with one of these categories of vulnerable person
  • having been looked after, accommodated or fostered and is aged 21 or over (other than 'relevant students')
  • having been a member of Her Majesty's regular naval, military or air forces
  • having served a custodial sentence, been committed for contempt of court or similar offence, or been remanded in custody
  • having had to leave accommodation because of violence or threats of violence from another person that are likely to be carried out.

When is a person vulnerable?

It is a matter of evaluative judgement whether the applicant’s circumstances make them vulnerable. The council should determine whether, if homeless, the applicant would be significantly more vulnerable than an ordinary person would be if they became homeless. The assessment must be a qualitative composite one taking into account all of the relevant facts and circumstances and involves a consideration of the impact of homelessness on the applicant when compared to an ordinary person if made homeless. The council should consider whether the applicant would suffer or be at risk of suffering harm or detriment which the ordinary person would not suffer or be at risk of suffering, such that the harm or detriment would make a noticeable difference to their ability to deal with the consequences of homelessness.

When assessing an applicant’s vulnerability, a council may take into account the services and support available to an applicant from a third party, including their family.

snippets.description: Explained: Reviews and Appeals
snippets.data:
The council must make decisions on any homelessness application in writing. These decisions can be challenged by an internal review. After the review they can be challenged by an appeal to the county court. The suitability of accommodation (except interim accommodation) can also be challenged by an internal review and then by appeal to the county court. You can accept the accommodation and seek a review.

There is a 21-day time limit for reviews and appeals to the county court. Legal Aid is available for both reviews and appeals and we recommend that legal advice is obtained. Legal advice can be obtained from Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453, Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444 or a solicitor.

snippets.description: Explained: Interim Duty to Accommodate
snippets.data:
A local authority must secure that accommodation is available while it makes inquiries as soon as it has reason to believe that the applicant may be:

  • homeless
  • eligible for assistance, and
  • in priority need.

The decision that the council makes will explain when the duty comes to an end.

snippets.description: Help available from council: Claim for possession has been issued at the court
snippets.data:
We have a legal duty to prevent homelessness. Firstly we need to check if you are eligible for assistance.

If you are eligible for assistance, we will check whether you have any legal defence to the claim for possession. If so, we will help you to make the defence or refer you to a housing advice centre or solicitor who can assist you. We will also negotiate with your landlord to try and keep you in your home.

If we cannot prevent your homelessness and you become homeless then we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council. If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally, we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer-term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

You can come to our Housing Contact Centre at Laurence House, 1 Catford Road, SE6 4RU, 10am-4pm, Monday to Friday. 

Alternatively you can call out council call centre on 020 8314 3020.

snippets.description: Explained: Local Connection
snippets.data:
A person has a local connection with the council due to:

  • normal residence
  • employment
  • family association
  • special circumstances
  • leaving care.
  • A former asylum seeker may have a local connection if they were provided with UKVI accommodation in an area.

The council will consider each case individually on its own particular facts.

A referral to another council on the basis of local connection can be made where the applicant or any person who might reasonably be expect to reside with her/him:

  • has no local connection with the council to which the application was made
  • has a local connection with the other council
  • will not be at risk of violence in the other council’s area.

A referral to another council may be made at the relief stage (to English councils only) or the main duty stage (to English, Scottish or Welsh councils).

snippets.description: Explained: Main Housing Duty
snippets.data:
Where the council has been unable to prevent or relieve homelessness and is satisfied that an applicant is eligible for assistance, in priority need, and unintentionally homeless then it owes the main housing duty.

However, the main duty is not owed where an applicant has:

  • turned down a suitable final accommodation or final Part 6 offer made by the authority in under the relief duty, or
  • been served a notice of deliberate and unreasonable refusal to cooperate with a step in the personalised housing plan.

The main housing duty can be met with an offer of either temporary or permanent accommodation. The authority can provide accommodation itself, through another landlord (including in the private sector) or by providing advice and assistance that is sufficient to secure accommodation. Any accommodation must be suitable.

snippets.description: Help available from council: Received notice of eviction from the bailiffs
snippets.data:
We have a legal duty to prevent homelessness. Firstly we need to check if you are eligible for assistance.

If you are eligible for assistance, we will consider whether the warrant of eviction can be stayed or suspended to allow you to remain in your home. If we think this is a possibility then we will help you to make the application or refer you to a housing advice centre or solicitor who can assist you. We will also negotiate with your landlord to try and keep you in your home.

If we cannot prevent your homelessness and you become homeless then we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council. If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally, we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer-term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

You can come to our Housing Contact Centre at Laurence House, 1 Catford Road, SE6 4RU, 10am-4pm, Monday to Friday. 

Alternatively you can call out council call centre on 020 8314 3020.

snippets.description: Help available form the council: Home is unsuitable due to disability or ill health
snippets.data:
We have a legal duty to prevent homelessness. Firstly we need to check if you are eligible for assistance. If you are eligible for assistance, we will consider whether your ill health or disability make you legally homeless. In doing so we may obtain medical reports and involve our medical advisor and/or occupational therapist. We may consider whether adaptations can be made to your home to make it suitable.

If it is impossible to make the home reasonable for you to continue to remain in, then we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council. If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally, we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer-term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

snippets.description: Help available from the council: I want to move
snippets.data:
We have a legal duties to prevent homelessness and provide housing advice. We will consider why you want to move and provide advice on the options that you have to find alternative accommodation. We will only have further duties to help you if you are legally homeless or at risk. You may also want advice about obtaining social housing.

If you would like more information about our schemes to help people move who currently live in Housing Associations or Council Housing, visit lewisham.gov.uk/myservices/housing/social/social-housing-tenants-who-would-like-to-move ;

snippets.description: Help available from council: Property conditions
snippets.data:
We have a legal duty to prevent homelessness. Firstly we need to check if you are eligible for assistance. If you are eligible for assistance, we will consider whether the conditions make you legally homeless. In doing so we will involve the Private Sector Housing Agency and we may serve an improvement notice or taking emergency remedial action. In most cases, this results in the conditions being improved.

However, if it is impossible to make the home reasonable for you to continue to remain in, then we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council. If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally, we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer-term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

snippets.description: Help available from the council: I have nowhere to put caravan, boat or mobile home that I live in
snippets.data:
We have a legal duty to relieve homelessness. If you live in a movable structure such as a caravan, mobile home or houseboat, and there is nowhere where that you have permission to put it and live in it, then we need to check if you are eligible for assistance.

We may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council. If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will try to find somewhere that you can put and live in your home. If not we will work with you to try to get you somewhere else to live. Legally, we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

snippets.description: EEA National concerned about Brexit on my rights
snippets.data:
The UK Government has set up dedicated web pages with advice on obtaining settled status. The European commissions has set up dedicated web pages with advice aimed specifically at EEA nationals.

Read Lewisham Council's Brexit guidance.

snippets.description: Ineligible EEA National - next steps
snippets.data:
As EEA Nationals who are workers are usually eligible for homelessness assistance, then one solution is to get a job. For help you can contact your local Jobcentre Plus. You can also use the Government Job Search. Even though you are not eligible for homelessness assistance you may still be entitled to claim certain social security benefits and you may be able to use this money to find somewhere to live or pay your rent.

The rules about benefit and housing eligibility for EEA nationals and their family members are very complicated and advice from a benefits or housing adviser​ should be sought. For housing advice contact Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444. For benefits advice contact Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453. The East European Resource Centre provides help and advice to Eastern European migrants.

snippets.description: EEA National and not eligible for homelessness assistance
snippets.data:
If a decision has been made that you are not eligible for homelessness assistance and you disagree with the decision, then you can seek a review of that decision. You should ask for the review within 21 days of being notified of the decision. You may want to take legal advice from Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444.

The following EEA Nationals are likely to be eligible:

  • Workers
  • Self-employed persons
  • Retired or incapacitated workers and self-employed people.
  • Family of workers and self-employed
  • People with five years' residence in the UK

snippets.description: Leaving hospital with nowhere to go
snippets.data:
If you are concerned that you will be homeless following a stay in hospital, you need to tell the nursing staff about your situation as soon as possible so they know you may be homeless on discharge. They will be able to make your situation known to the hospital discharge team for advice. Many hospitals have specialist discharge workers who can help with housing options. Hospitals also have a duty to refer you to a housing authority.

Before they can make a referral, they must have your consent to do so. You will be asked to which housing authority in England you would like to be referred. It is sensible to ask to be referred to the local authority with which you have the strongest local connection, as they will be best equipped to help you.

We have a legal duty to prevent homelessness. Firstly we need to check if you are eligible for assistance. If you are eligible for assistance, we will consider where you were living before you were admitted to hospital, whether you can return there and whether that accommodation would be suitable. We may consider whether the accommodation could be adapted to meet your needs. If you have nowhere to go, you should not be discharged from hospital until arrangements have been made for you to stay somewhere.

If you have no suitable accommodation, then we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council. If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally, we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection. If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer-term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

We will also consider whether you have ‘eligible needs’ under the Care Act 2014. You have eligible needs if:

  • you need care and support as a result of a physical or mental condition; AND
  • because of this, there are at least 2 ‘specified outcomes’ that you cannot achieve in day-to-day life. These specified outcomes can be found listed here; AND
  • as a result, there is a significant impact on your well-being.

If we think that you meet the criteria, then we will refer you to Lewisham Council Adult Social Care Team for a Care Act assessment.

snippets.description: Help available from council: Landlord has served notice
snippets.data:
We have a legal duty to prevent homelessness. We will check whether the notice is valid. If the notice is not valid then we will give you housing advice.

If the notice is valid then we need to check if you are eligible for assistance. If you are eligible for assistance, we will negotiate with your landlord to try and keep you in your home and protect your rights to live there.

If we cannot prevent your homelessness and you become homeless then we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council. If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer-term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

You can come to our Housing Contact Centre at Laurence House, 1 Catford Road, SE6 4RU, 10am-4pm, Monday to Friday. 

Alternatively you can call out council call centre on 020 8314 3020.

snippets.description: Help available from the council: Friend or family asked me to leave
snippets.data:
We have a legal duty to prevent homelessness. Firstly we need to check if you are eligible for assistance. We will contact the family member or friend who has asked you to leave and try to mediate to keep you in your home.

If we cannot prevent your homelessness and you become homeless then we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council. If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

You can come to our Housing Contact Centre at Laurence House, 1 Catford Road, SE6 4RU, 10am-4pm, Monday to Friday. 

Alternatively you can call out council call centre on 020 8314 3020.

snippets.description: Help available from the council: I am rough sleeping
snippets.data:
We have a legal duty to relieve homelessness. Firstly we need to check if you are eligible for assistance. If you are eligible for assistance, or if we cannot decide whether you are, we will do our best to help you to find somewhere to stay tonight.

We may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council. If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally, we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

snippets.description: Help available from council: Asked to leave by parents
snippets.data:
We have a legal duty to prevent homelessness. Firstly we need to check if you are eligible for assistance. We will contact your parents and try to mediate to keep you in your home. If you are under 18 then we may involve Children’s Services, who may carry out an assessment under the Children Act.

If we cannot prevent your homelessness and you become homeless then we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council. If you are under 18 then Children’s Services may have a duty to accommodate you. If you are over 18 and we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

To speak to a Housing Solutions Officer you can come to our Housing Contact Centre at Laurence House, 1 Catford Road, SE6 4RU, 10am-4pm, Monday to Friday.

Please bring documents that evidence your situation. These could be:

  • Your passport or drivers licence

  • Recent payslips or letters about benefits you are claiming

  • Letters from your landlord

  • Letters from friends or family who you currently live with explaining why you can no longer stay there

  • Information about any health conditions you have or if you are pregnant

  • Information about your children if they live with you.


Your first meeting will be a quick conversation to assess how we can help.  If we need a longer conversation then we will book an appointment for you.

You can also call Lewisham Council call centre on 020 8314 3020 for more advice about our services.

snippets.description: Help available from the council: I can't continue to live in my home due to fire / flood
snippets.data:
We have a legal duty to prevent homelessness. Firstly we need to check if you are eligible for assistance. If you are eligible for assistance, we will consider whether your home is habitable. In doing so we may involve the Private Sector Housing Agency and they may serve an improvement notice or taking emergency remedial action. We will also consider whether you or your landlord has any insurance which would pay for repairs or alternative accommodation.

If it is impossible to make the home reasonable for you to continue to remain in, then we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council. If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally, we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

snippets.description: Help available from the council: We are overcrowded
snippets.data:
We have a legal duty to prevent homelessness. Firstly we will consider whether your home is overcrowded and whether this makes unreasonable for you to continue to live there. In doing so we may involve Private Sector Housing Agency. If it is not reasonable for you to continue to occupy your home due to overcrowding then we need to check if you are eligible for assistance.

If we cannot prevent your homelessness then we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council. If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer-term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

snippets.description: Find help in this area if you are rough sleeping
snippets.data:
You should come to your local council for advice and assistance. We will:

  • Do our best to help you find somewhere to sleep tonight
  • Work with you to end your homelessness

If it is outside of office hours or you do not want to come to the council then you should contact StreetLink (the national rough sleeper referral service). You can also download the StreetLink app from iTunes or the Google Play store

You can also visit a day centre for people experiencing homelessness. Homeless Link provides a searchable database of homelessness services so you can find the nearest option for you. Day centres can help you by providing:

  • Food, shelter and washing facilities
  • Housing advice
  • Skills and employment training
  • Social and support networks.

If you have a particular need, staff at a day centre will be able to direct you to the help you need. Sleeping rough should be a last resort. If you currently have housing, try to do everything you can to keep it.

snippets.description: I'm from abroad and want to return home
snippets.data:
You can apply for help to return to your home country. This is known as ‘voluntary return’. You can still get help if you’re already making your own plans to return to your home country. If you’re eligible for financial support, you can apply for up to £2,000 which you can use to find somewhere to live, find a job or start a business in your home country.

You can get help to return home if any of the following are true:

  • you’re in the UK illegally or have overstayed your visa or permission to stay
  • you’re in a family group with a child under 18 and are in the UK illegally
  • you’ve withdrawn, or want to withdraw, your application to stay in the UK
  • you’ve claimed asylum in the UK but now want to withdraw that claim

For more information contact the Home Office helpline: 0300 004 0202 (Monday to Friday, 9am - 5.30pm) or look at this online Government site.

snippets.description: I am concerned for somebody that is rough sleeping
snippets.data:
If you are concerned about someone you have seen sleeping rough, you can use a website to send an alert to StreetLink. The details you provide are sent to the local authority or outreach service for the area in which you have seen the person, to help them find the individual and connect them to support.

You can also download the StreetLink app from iTunes or the Google Play store

Outreach Teams and local support services go out late at night and early in the morning to look for people sleeping on the streets. They use the information provided by people like you to find individuals who are sleeping rough, assess their needs, and move them into accommodation. Many people sleeping rough have complex needs. We’ll work with them, taking the time to build trust and explain the help that is available.

snippets.description: Severe Weather Emergency Protocol
snippets.data: The Severe Weather Emergency Protocol (SWEP) is used when severe weather is forecast. The protocol is implemented and emergency accommodation is made available for rough sleepers on the first night of the forecast of severe weather. SWEP is usually available in winter when the temperature decreases. Contact Lewisham Council Housing Team on 020 8314 3020 for more information on how to access SWEP.

snippets.description: Ineligible Swiss National - next steps
snippets.data:
As Swiss Nationals who are workers are usually eligible for homelessness assistance, then one solution is to get a job. For help you can contact your local Jobcentre Plus. You can also use the Government Job Search. Even though you are not eligible for homelessness assistance you may still be entitled to claim certain social security benefits and you may be able to use this money to find somewhere to live or pay your rent.

The rules about benefit and housing eligibility for Swiss nationals and their family members are very complicated and advice from a benefits or housing adviser​ should be sought. For housing advice contact Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444. For benefits advice contact Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453.

snippets.data:
If a decision has been made that you are not eligible for homelessness assistance and you disagree with the decision, then you can seek a review of that decision. You should ask for the review within 21 days of being notified of the decision. You may want to take legal advice from Shelter advice line on 0808 800 4444.
