snippets.description: Swiss National concerned about Brexit on my rights
snippets.data: The UK Government has set up dedicated web pages with advice on how to prepare if the UK leaves the EU without a deal. The UK Government has set up dedicated web pages with advice on obtaining settle status. The European commissions has set up dedicated web pages with advice aimed specifically at EEA nationals.

snippets.description: Non EEA/Swiss national - concerned about immigration status
snippets.data:
You can get advice if you are concerned about your immigration status from:

  • The Joint Council for the Welfare of Immigrants:
  • Migrants Resource Centre:
  • The Refugee Council:
  • Refugee Action:

You can find other immigration advisers here:

snippets.description: What are not public funds?
snippets.data:
A person with No Recourse to Public Funds (NRPF) can rent a property from a housing association if they have applied directly to the housing association rather than through their local council’s housing allocations list. An allocation of a housing association property will only be considered to be a public fund if it has been obtained through the council's list.

Legal Aid is not considered a public fund.

Public funds do not include benefits that are based on National Insurance contributions. National Insurance is paid in the same way as income tax and is based on earnings. Benefits to which a person is entitled as a result of National Insurance contributions include:

  • contribution-based jobseeker’s allowance
  • incapacity benefit
  • retirement pension
  • widow’s benefit and bereavement benefit
  • guardian’s allowance
  • statutory maternity pay

In addition:

  • A person with NRPF can claim child maintenance from a former partner through the statutory Child Maintenance Service.
  • Some local authorities operate concessionary travel passes for people who are elderly or have a disability​. People with NRPF are not prohibited from applying for these, but will have to satisfy the relevant eligibility criteria to obtain one
  • Children with NRPF can receive state school education whilst they are of compulsory school age. However, ​when a condition of a child's immigration permission does not permit study, or study at a state school, they will not be able receive a state school education.
  • In England, all children in reception, years 1 and 2 at state schools (including free schools and academies) automatically get free school meals. After this Children with NRPF wil not be able to get free school meals.
  • Government funded childcare is not a public fund for immigration purposes, so if a person who has leave to remain with NRPF is included in their partner's application, they will not be in breach of their immigration conditions.
  • Some types of healthcare are free to everyone and can be accessed by people regardless of their immigration status, including:
  • GP services
  • NHS Walk in centres
  • Treatment for certain contagious diseases
  • Accident and emergency treatment at a hospital

Other NHS treatment that may not be free.

  • Social services assistance can be provided – see Other help and support

snippets.description: What are public funds?
snippets.data:
Public funds include housing support and a range of benefits that are given to people on a low income:

Housing Support

  • local authority homelessness assistance
  • an allocation of local authority housing (for example, from the housing register)

Benefits:

  • income-based jobseeker’s allowance
  • income support
  • child tax credit
  • universal credit
  • working tax credit
  • a social fund payment
  • child benefit
  • housing benefit
  • council tax benefit
  • council tax reduction
  • domestic rate relief (Northern Ireland)
  • state pension credit
  • attendance allowance
  • severe disablement allowance
  • personal independence payment
  • carer’s allowance
  • disability living allowance

snippets.description: No recourse to public funds - other help and support
snippets.data:
If you're an asylum seeker or have been refused asylum and don’t have anywhere to stay you should call an asylum helpline.

If you have no recourse to public funds then you may still be able to get housing and financial support. Assistance can be provided to:

  • Families, where there is a child in need (for example, because the child is homeless or the parent cannot afford to meet the family's basic living needs)
  • Young people who were formerly looked after by a local authority, for example, because they were an unaccompanied asylum seeking child (UASC), or other separated migrant child
  • Adults requiring care and support due to a disability, illness or mental health condition

However the assistance is not provided by the housing department of the local council, but either by Children’s Services (for families with children) or Adult Services (both part of social services). In this area, you would need to contact or

To establish eligibility for assistance, the local authority will undertake the following assessments:

  • Families - a child in need assessment
  • Adults with care needs - a needs assessment ​

You can contact Lewisham Council Children's Social Care Team on 020 8314 6660.

You can contact Lewisham Council Adult Social Care Team on 020 8314 7777.

In many cases, social services can only provide housing and financial support when this is necessary to prevent a breach of the person or family's human rights or rights under the European treaties. When the exclusion applies, social services will need to carry out a human rights assessment as well as a needs assessment to establish whether help can be given.

Other help and support:

  • Red Cross
  • Refugee Action
  • Refugee Council
  • Project 17 (Advice and advocacy for families with migrant children)

snippets.description: Reporting disrepair if you are a licencee
snippets.data:
If you are not a tenant or a homeowner, then any repair rights will depend on the terms of you licence to occupy the property. You should report the repair to the owner of the property or the agent. You should do this in writing (by email, text or letter) or if it is urgent by phone and confirm it in writing. You should keep a copy of what you send.

If the repair has not been completed in a reasonable period of time then you should report the problem to the Private Sector Housing Agency on 020 8314 3020. We will inspect your home and if we find that there are category 1 or category 2 hazards we will take enforcement action.

snippets.description: Should I withhold rent due to the disrepair?
snippets.data: Whilst it is tempting to think that if you withhold rent then your landlord will carry out the repairs, this does not work. You do not have the right to withhold rent because of your landlord's failure to do repairs. If you withhold rent your landlord may start possession proceedings against you and put you at risk of eviction and homelessness. If you become homeless as a result you may be intentionally homeless.

snippets.description: Reporting repairs for temporary accommodation
snippets.data: If you need to report a repair for your temporary accommodation, you should call Lewisham Council Housing Options Team on 020 8314 3020.

snippets.description: Report the problem to your landlord or agent
snippets.data: The first step is to report the repair to your landlord or the agent. You should do this in writing (by email, text or letter) or if it is urgent by phone and confirm it in writing. You should keep a copy of what you send. Advice Now has a guide on how to get repairs done at your privately rented home, which includes tips on writing a letter.

snippets.description: Steps to take if your landlord or agent does not act on disrepair
snippets.data:
You must allow your landlord and/or his or her contractors access to your home at reasonable times to allow the repairs to be completed. If you do not allow access then you cannot take action to get the repairs carried out. Unless it’s an emergency, they must give you at least 24 hours' written notice.

If the repair has not been completed in a reasonable period of time then you can take action. The action that you should take depends on the urgency, whether the disrepair is affecting your health or safety and how much loss you have incurred (for example, through belongings being damaged). You should take the following steps:

  • Report the problem to the Private Sector Housing Agency on 020 8314 3020. We will inspect your home and if we find that there are category 1 or category 2 hazards we will take enforcement action. If we serve a notice on the landlord this will prevent the landlord using Section 21 to evict you.
  • If the disrepair is affecting your health and safety or the health and safety or of a family member that lives with you then you should get advice from either Shelter on 0808 800 4444 or Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453. Legal Aid is available for such cases. You can check if you financially qualify for Legal Aid here.

snippets.description: Worried that if I complain about the disrepair I may get evicted
snippets.data: If you are an assured or protected tenant then you cannot be evicted for complaining. If you are an Assured Shorthold Tenant then there is a risk, although there is protection if the Council serves a notice on the landlord. If you are concerned then you should contact Lewisham Council Housing Team on 020 8314 3020 for advice and we will do everything we can to prevent you from being evicted.

snippets.description: Making a claim of more than £10,000 against your landlord for repairs
snippets.data:
If you have a claim worth more than £10,000 then you should get legal advice.

You may be able to get a solicitor to act for you without you making any payment to them using one of the following:

  • Conditional fees, more commonly known as a 'no win, no fee' arrangement, mean that you do not have to pay your solicitors costs upfront. If you win the case, your solicitor's fees will mostly be paid by the other side. If you lose, you don't have to pay your solicitor's fees. You may be asked to take out an insurance policy to pay for the other side's costs if you lose.
  • Damages-based agreements are another type of 'no win, no fee' arrangement. Here your lawyer gets paid by taking a percentage of the amount of compensation you are awarded. You may have to take out insurance against the costs of losing.

You can find a solicitor here and find advice on choosing a solicitor here.

snippets.description: Making a claim of less than £10,000 against your landlord for repairs
snippets.data:
If your claim is for less than £10,000 then this will be a small claim. Read more about small claims.

If you are seeking an order forcing the landlord to carry out repairs then the upper limit of a claim on the small claims track is £1,000. If you want to seek an order forcing the landlord to carry out repairs then you should get advice first.

To bring a claim you will need:

  • To prove that the landlord was on notice of the disrepair (which you should have reported in writing); and
  • To prove that the landlord was responsible for the repair; and
  • To prove that the landlord has failed to remedy the defects within a reasonable period of time of being told about them; and
  • Expert evidence is usually required in disrepair cases, but you can use the report prepared by the Private Sector Housing Agency and any notices that they served; and
  • You will need evidence of your losses. You will need to prepare a schedule listing each item with the value of the item. Photographs of the damaged or destroyed belongings will help (use a date and time stamp on your phone).

To start the claim you must first follow the steps in the Pre-action Protocol for Disrepair Claims (a failure to do so may result in cost consequences).

You must bring a claim within 6 years of the disrepair (but it is better to bring it earlier).

You will have to pay a court fee unless you are exempt. Find out about help with court fees.

Taking court action is a formal process and you must comply with the rules of the court.

If you lose your claim then you may have to pay your landlord’s legal costs.

You can get advice from Shelter on 0808 800 4444.

The LawWorks Clinics Network provides free initial advice to individuals.

snippets.description: The disrepair at your council home is minor but has still not been addressed
snippets.data:
If the repair is a qualifying repair and the repair costs less than an estimated cost of £250, then providing the Council was responsible for the repair, then the Council must issue a repair notice to a contractor and send you a copy with information on how the right to repair scheme works. There will be a time limit for the contractor to do the work by, which will depend on the repair needed.

If the repair work isn't done within the specified time limit, you need to ask Council for another contractor to do the work. If another contractor is available, your landlord must issue a repair notice to them and send you a copy. Your landlord can only use contractors on their list.

If the repair is not a qualifying repair, you can take some or all of the following steps:

  • Report the disrepair again.
  • Go and see your local councillor about the disrepair.
  • Ask your Tenants and Residents Association to take up the problem.
  • Make a formal complaint.

If your complaint is rejected then you can complain to the Housing Ombudsman Service either via a designated person or eight weeks after the Council has given you its final response to your complaint. You can find more information about the Housing Ombudsman Service and complaints here.

snippets.description: The disrepair is urgent and/or affecting my health or safety
snippets.data: If the disrepair is urgent and/or affecting your health and safety or the health and safety or of a family member that lives with you then you should get advice from either Shelter on 0808 800 4444 or Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453. Legal Aid is available for such cases. You can check if you financially qualify for Legal Aid here.

snippets.description: Using the qualifying repair procedure to claim compensation
snippets.data:
If the repair is a qualifying repair and the repair costs less than an estimated cost of £250, then providing the Council was responsible for the repair, then the Council must issue a repair notice to a contractor and send you a copy with information on how the right to repair scheme works. There will be a time limit for the contractor to do the work by, which will depend on the repair needed.

If the repair work isn't done within the specified time limit, you need to ask Council for another contractor to do the work. If another contractor is available, your landlord must issue a repair notice to them and send you a copy. Your landlord can only use contractors on their list. If the second contractor didn't do the repair work within the time limit, you are entitled to get £10 in compensation. For every extra day you had to wait, you are entitled to another £2. The most compensation you can get for any one job is £50.

snippets.description: Make a complaint to the council
snippets.data: Make a complaint to this council. If your complaint is rejected then you can complain to the Housing Ombudsman Service either via a designated person or eight weeks after the Council has given you its final response to your complaint. Find out more information about the Housing Ombudsman Service and complaints.

snippets.description: Report the problem to your landlord
snippets.data: The first step is to report the repair to your landlord. You should do this using either their online reporting service on their dedicated repairs phone number. If you report the repairs by phone you should confirm it in writing. You should keep a copy of what you send.

snippets.description: Steps to take if your landlord does not act on the disrepair
snippets.data:
You must allow your landlord and their contractors access to your home at reasonable times to allow the repairs to be completed. If you do not allow access then you cannot take action to get the repairs carried out. Unless it’s an emergency, they must give you at least 24 hours' written notice.

If the repair has not been completed in a reasonable period of time then you can take action. For advice on what is a reasonable period of time use the links on the right. The action that you should take depends on the urgency, whether the disrepair is affecting your health or safety and how much loss you have incurred (for example, through belongings being damaged). You should take the following steps:

  • Report the problem to the Private Sector Housing Agency on 020 8314 3020. We will inspect your home and if we find that there are category 1 or category 2 hazards we will take enforcement action.
  • If the disrepair is affecting your health and safety or the health and safety or of a family member that lives with you then you should get advice from either Shelter on 0808 800 4444 or Advice Lewisham on 0800 231 5453. Legal Aid is available for such cases. You can check if you financially qualify for Legal Aid here.

snippets.description: Make a complaint to the housing association
snippets.data:
A Housing Association must have a complaints process. You will find this on their website or you can ask your housing officer.

If your complaint is rejected then you can complain to the Housing Ombudsman Service either via a designated person or eight weeks after your landlord has given you its final response to your complaint. You can find more information about the Housing Ombudsman Service and complaints here.

snippets.description: Leaseholder needing repairs
snippets.data:
Under the terms of most leases, the landlord (freeholder) is responsible for repairs to the exterior (outside) of the flats and the leaseholder is responsible for repairs to the interior (inside) of the flat. To work out exactly who is responsible for what (for example front doors and windows) you will need to check your lease. If the property is a house then again you will need to check the lease.

You can get free advice from the Leasehold Advisory Service (which is a government funded service set up to help leaseholders understand their rights and obligations).

You may be able to claim on your home insurance policy for the cost of repairs. If you need advice about this then you can contact the Financial Ombudsman Service.

In certain circumstances you may be able to get help with improvements.

snippets.description: Freeholder needing repairs
snippets.data:
Freeholders are responsible for the repair of their homes.

You may be able to claim on your home insurance policy for the cost of repairs. If you need advice about this then you can contact the Financial Ombudsman Service.

In certain circumstances you may be able to get help with improvements.

fields.value: get help with improvements

snippets.description: My home is in disrepair, does this make me homeless?
snippets.data:
We will consider whether the conditions are so bad in your home that it is no longer reasonable for you and your household to continue to occupy it. In doing so we may have regard to the general housing circumstances prevailing in local district.

Our first duty is to try and prevent homelessness, so we will use our powers to improve the conditions in your home. We may arrange for you to be housed temporarily whilst repairs are carried out, if the repairs cannot be done whilst you live there. Only if it is not possible for your home to be made reasonable for you and your household to continue to occupy it will you be homeless.

snippets.description: I want to improve my home to make it suitable for me
snippets.data:
Help may be available from the following organisations, whether you rent or own your home. If you rent your home you may need permission from your landlord to make some improvements.

  • The Foundations Independent Living Trust (FILT) (a charity) helps older and vulnerable people live with dignity in their own homes. They operate funds which enable local home improvement agencies (HIAs) to provide a range of support measures and they distribute Corporate Social Responsibility and charity funds to HIAs so you can deliver fast and effective service by assessing customer need and carrying out the necessary work.
  • Care & Repair England is a small, national charitable organisation set up to improve the homes and living conditions of older people. They can help with home repairs and adaptations.
  • Energy Company Obligation can take steps to make your home needs to be made warmer, this assistance could cover things like insulation or a new A-rated boiler. Usually you will you need to be getting certain means-tested or income-related benefits to qualify for a grant.
  • The Council may be able to offer help with home improvements. Contact Lewisham Housing Assistance Team on housingassistance@lewisham.gov.uk.
  • If you are disabled then you can apply for a disabled facilities grant for work that is essential to help a disabled person live an independent life. This is paid by the Council. Contact Lewisham Housing Assistance Team on housingassistance@lewisham.gov.uk.

snippets.description: Care leaver aged 16 or 17
snippets.data: If you’re a 16 or 17-year-old care leaver and are homeless, then you should urgently contact on 020 8314 6660. Alternatively, you can contact the Lewisham Council Housing Team on 020 8314 3020. The Lewisham Council Children's Social Care Team are initially responsible for assessing your needs, and we will arrange for this to happen, with our involvement. We will make sure you are not on the streets.

snippets.description: Care leaver aged 18 to 21
snippets.data:
We have a legal duty to prevent homelessness. Firstly we need to check if you are eligible for assistance. We will look at where you have been living and, if it is suitable, we will try to keep you there. If we cannot prevent your homelessness and you become homeless then we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council. If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then, provided you spent a minimum of one night in care when you were 16 or 17, you will have a priority need for housing. If not we will consider whether you have another priority need. We will also consider whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If the council placed you in care outside of the district, you will still have a ‘local connection’ to the council who placed you. If you have lived outside the area for 2 years or more, you would also have a local connection to the area you were placed in, and could apply on the housing register there, too.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

snippets.description: Care leaver aged 21 or over
snippets.data:
We have a legal duty to prevent homelessness. Firstly we need to check if you are eligible for assistance. We will look at where you have been living and, if it is suitable, we will try to keep you there. If we cannot prevent your homelessness and you become homeless then we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council. If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection. If the council placed you in care outside of the district, you will still have a ‘local connection’ to the council who placed you. If you have lived outside the area for 2 years or more, you would also have a local connection to the area you were placed in, and could apply on the housing register there, too.

You will have a priority need if you are vulnerable as a result of having been looked after, accommodated or fostered (except a person who is a ‘relevant student’). We will consider these (and other) factors:

  • the length of time that you were looked after, accommodated or fostered;
  • the reasons why you were looked after, accommodated or fostered;
  • the length of time since you left care, and whether you have been able to obtain and maintain accommodation during any of that period;
  • whether you have any existing support networks, particularly including family, friends or a mentor.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

snippets.description: I want to know about my rights as a care leaver
snippets.data:
If you have recently left care then you may get help from the council with your accommodation and finances, through Lewisham Council Children's Social Care Team. You can contact Lewisham Council Children's Social Care Team on 020 8314 6660.

To qualify for the most help, you must have spent a total of 13 weeks in care from the age of 14. This must include at least a day when you were 16 or 17. Help from the council's children’s services department can start when you turn 16 and last until you’re 21, or until you finish training or higher education.

Before you left care, you should have been allocated a personal adviser from the council to work with you to make sure you're ready for independent living. You should have been given a pathway plan setting out clear goals for your development. This should be reviewed every 6 months, or whenever there’s a big change in your life. You should have personal adviser and pathway plan support until you’re 21, or until you finish training or higher education.

The following organisations can help you:

The Children's Commissioner's Office will give you confidential advice and information about your situation and answer any questions you have: Phone (free) 0800 528 0731

Child Law Advice is provided by Coram Children's Legal Centre, the UK's leading legal children's charity, and is part of the Coram group. Phone 0300 330 5480

Barnardo’s supports young people leaving care. They can help you find somewhere to live and in some cases provide supported lodgings.

snippets.description: Mutual exchange
snippets.data:
If you are a current council or housing association tenant you can seek a mutual exchange with another social housing tenant. You must get permission from your landlord and follow the proper process. You could be evicted if you try to exchange your tenancy without permission. The tenant you are swapping with must also get permission from their landlord. You can use a tenancy exchange website to help find another tenant to swap homes with, for example:

  • Homeswapper
  • House Exchange
  • Exchange Locata

Some sites charge a fee for registration. Your landlord may have an arrangement that allows you to use a home swap website for free. When you register online to use a tenancy exchange service, you are asked details about your current home, the kind of home you're looking for and where you want to live. Once you have registered, you can get details of properties, make contact with other tenants and arrange to view their homes. When you find a suitable property and you and the other tenant are happy to swap, you can ask your landlord for permission to exchange. Your landlord has six weeks to decide whether or not to give you permission to exchange your tenancy.

It is illegal for you or the other tenant to charge a fee as part of the tenancy exchange. You could be evicted if you charge or receive any money to swap your home. Before you agree to a tenancy exchange, check what your tenancy rights will be in a new home. You may have different or fewer rights with your new tenancy. We can give you further advice if you are not sure what your rights will be. Some tenancy exchanges must be transferred using a deed of assignment. This is a legal document that must be signed by an independent witness. We or your landlord can check if you need to do this.

snippets.description: Explained: Homelessness: reasonable to remain
snippets.data:
In considering whether it is reasonable to for you remain in your home, we will consider a number of factors:

  • Whether you or a member of your household are subject to domestic abuse or other violence
  • If your home is affordable
  • Whether your home is available for occupation for you and any other person who normally resides with you as a member of the family or any other person who might reasonably be expected to reside with you
  • If your home is overcrowded
  • If your home is in poor state of repair and whether it can be repaired within a reasonable period of time.
  • The physical layout of the home and any disabilities that you or a member of you household have
  • Any harassment you are experiencing

We may make a comparison between your home and the general housing circumstances in the district, for example when considering overcrowding or disrepair. We may also consider it reasonable for you to continue to occupy your home where you have been served with notice, but we are trying to prevent you becoming homeless.

This is not an exhaustive list and we must take account of all relevant factors when considering whether it is reasonable for you to continue to occupy accommodation. If we do consider that it is reasonable for you to remain in your home we will tell you in writing why we have made that decision.

snippets.description: Armed forces - discharged
snippets.data:
If you are homeless on discharge then you should contact us urgently on 020 8314 3020.

We have a legal duty to prevent homelessness. Firstly we need to check if you are eligible for assistance. If you are eligible for assistance then we will consider where you are currently living and whether it is suitable.

If we cannot prevent your homelessness, then we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area. The law allows you to establish a local connection with an area where you have been posted, even though that posting may not have been of your own choosing. If we decide that you still do not have a local connection with this area, we may refer you to another Council

In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

A person who is vulnerable as a result of having been a member of Her Majesty’s regular armed forces (a veteran) has a priority need for accommodation. In considering whether veterans are vulnerable (as set out in paragraph 6.9 above) as a result of their time spent in the forces, a housing authority may wish to take into account the following factors:

  • the length of time you spent in the armed forces (although we will not assume that vulnerability could not occur as a result of a short period of service);
  • the type of service you were engaged in (those on active service may find it more difficult to cope with civilian life);
  • whether you spent any time in a military hospital (this could be an indicator of a serious health problem or of post-traumatic stress);
  • whether HM Forces’ medical and welfare advisers have judged you to be particularly vulnerable in their view and have issued a Medical History Release Form giving a summary of the circumstances causing that vulnerability;
  • the length of time since you left the armed forces, and whether you have been able to obtain and/or maintain accommodation during that time; and,
  • whether you have any existing support networks, particularly by way of family or friends.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer-term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

Veterans’ Gateway is made up of a consortium of organisations and Armed Forces charities, including The Royal British Legion, SSAFA – the Armed Forces charity, Poppy Scotland, Combat Stress and Connect Assist. They provide housing advice and help: 0808 802 1212 or text 81212

If you are a homeless who needs immediate support then get in touch with SSAFA - the armed forces charity. If in London call the London Homeless Division on 020 7828 2468 otherwise call contact SSAFA's central team on 0800 731 4880.

fields.value: contact us

snippets.description: Armed forces still serving
snippets.data:
To apply to us for social / affordable housing, we require applicants to have a local connection to this area. We will consider you have a local connection to this area if you are a serving member of the armed forces or have been discharged from the forces within the last 5 years. You will also qualify if you are a bereaved spouse leaving services family accommodation or are a former or serving member of the reserve forces, who needs to move because of injury or illness sustained as a result of service.

You can get specialist advice from the Ministry of Defence's (MOD) housing advice service - the Joint Service Housing Advice Office (JSHAO) - before you leave the forces. The JSHAO also runs the MOD referral scheme which may help you to find a housing association home. JSHAO telephone advice line: 01252 787574

Veterans’ Gateway is made up of a consortium of organisations and Armed Forces charities, including The Royal British Legion, SSAFA – the Armed Forces charity, Poppy Scotland, Combat Stress and Connect Assist. They provide housing advice and help: 0808 802 1212 or text 81212

snippets.description: I am in prison or youth detention
snippets.data:
Most prisons have a resettlement service called Through the Gate. The service is delivered by charities including Shelter, St Giles Trust and Catch22. The Resettlement Worker can help with benefits advice and referrals to suitable accommodation if you'll be homeless on release.

You can apply for the following grants before release:

  • a £46 discharge grant
  • up to £50 for your first night's accommodation (paid direct to the housing provider)

NACRO offer resettlement advice to offenders including housing, employment, education, training and health. Contact Nacro on 0800 0181 259 (from prison).

If your release is being supervised under MAPPA (Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements), then the MAPPA panel will be working closely with landlords prior to you moving into a property. This is to ensure that nobody is put at risk, and that aspects of the local community are taken into consideration.

It may be a condition of your release from prison that you live in Approved Premises (formerly known as probation or bail hostels). If it is a condition of your release to live in Approved Premises, your probation officer or offender manager will make the referral. Most people stay in Approved Premises for six months to one year. Only a minority of released prisoners are required to live in Approved Premises upon release. If you are not required to do so, it is your responsibility to get advice about where you will live upon release.

You need a suitable address to stay at before you can be released on bail or home detention curfew (an electronic tag). If you can’t live at your usual address, court or prison staff may refer you to the Bail Accommodation Support Scheme (BASS).

If you will be homeless on your release from prison then you can seek help from any housing authority (local council). If you want us to help you then you should contact us up to 56 days before the your release (the earlier the better). Prisons and Youth Offender Institutions also have a duty to refer you to a housing authority, if they believe you are threatened with homelessness. Before they can make a referral, they must have your consent to do so. You will be asked to which housing authority in England you would like to be referred. It is sensible to ask to be referred to the local authority with which you have the strongest local connection, if you will not be at risk there. That authority will be best equipped to help you. You will not have a local connection with the district where you have been detained, unless you had a connection with that area previously.

We have a legal duty to relieve homelessness. Firstly we need to check if you are eligible for assistance. If you are eligible for assistance, we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council, as long as you would not be at risk of violence.

If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally, we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

snippets.description: I have been released from prison or youth detention
snippets.data:
If you have been released from prison or youth detention, then we can help. You can contact us on Lewisham Council Housing Team.

We have a legal duty to relieve homelessness. Firstly we need to check if you are eligible for assistance. If you are eligible for assistance, we may consider whether you have a local connection with this area and, if not, we may refer you to another council, as long as you would not be at risk of violence. You will not have a local connection with the district where you have been detained, unless you had a connection with that area previously.

If we don’t refer you to another council we will try and relieve your homelessness. We will do this by working with you to try to get you somewhere to live. Legally, we have to do this for a period of 56 days. In trying to prevent or relieve your homelessness we will carry out an assessment of your housing situation and needs and draw up a Personalised Housing Plan in agreement with you.

If we cannot relieve your homelessness then we will consider whether you have a priority need for housing, whether you are intentionally homeless and we may consider whether you have a local connection.

If you are eligible, unintentionally homeless, and in priority need then you will be owed a longer term housing duty. We may refer you to another local council. If not we will arrange housing for you, which may be in the private sector.

There are, however, a number of specialist organisations who may be better able to help you to find accommodation:

  • The National Probation Service supervises high-risk offenders released into the community. If you are being supervised on your release then your Probation Officer may be able to help you find accommodation.
  • Community Rehabilitation Companies are responsible for managing low and medium risk offenders released into the community or serving community sentences. If you are being supervised then your Probation case manager may be able to help you find accommodation.
  • Youth offending teams are part of the council and are separate from the police and the courts. If you are a young offender, they may help you with accommodation. Find your local youth offending team.
  • NACRO offer resettlement advice to offenders including housing, employment, education and training and health. Contact Nacro on 0300 123 1999
  • Women in Prison offers dedicated housing support to women affected by the Criminal Justice System both in prison and in the community: 0800 953 0125
  • NACRO Homes Agency is a social lettings agency, specialising in supporting and securing homes for people who are homeless or experiencing insecure housing. It is suitable for those that require low level support.
  • Clink’s Directory of Offender Services provides a database of organisations working with people with convictions and their families. 020 7383 0966
  • Howard League for Penal Reform is a Helpline which offers advice on a range of issues affecting young people in custody. Phone 0808 801 0308.
  • St Giles Trust is a charity helping people facing severe disadvantage to find jobs, homes and the support they need; this includes support services in prisons and on release from custody: Phone 020 7703 7000.

snippets.description: Hostels or night shelters
snippets.data:
There are a variety of different types of hostels and shelters run by voluntary organisations and housing associations. They all have different acceptance criteria.

You can also contact Shelter’s free housing advice helpline on 0808 800 4444 or use the Homelesslink website to find this type of accommodation in your area.

In a hostel you are likely to be given a licence agreement with sets out the rules under which you can stay there. You must ensure that you pay the rent and comply with the rules.

snippets.description: Staying with friends or relatives
snippets.data: This could be the best and most cost-effective option in the short or medium term. Whilst staying with friends or relatives, it is reasonable to pay money for your family’s keep, but it may enable you to save up for a deposit and rent in advance for your own place.

snippets.description: Foyers and supported housing
snippets.data:
In some areas there are housing projects for young people called Foyers that provide help with getting into training or employment, budgeting, as well as accommodation. Contact the Foyer Federation for more details on 020 7430 2212 or search for a Foyer here.

In a Foyer you are likely to be given a licence agreement with sets out the rules under which you can stay there. You must ensure that you pay the rent and comply with the rules.

Lewisham Council commissions three supported housing pathways for single people that may be accessible via the Housing Solutions Service as part of a Personal Housing Plan for Homeless single people. The pathways are divided into Young Persons Supported Housing, Mental Health Supported Housing and Vulnerable Adults Supported Housing.

If you would like to enquire about this, you can contact ship@lewisham.gov.uk

snippets.description: Lodging schemes for young people
snippets.data:
These schemes are sometimes called Nightstop schemes. A young person stays in a room in another person’s house. This person will often have received some training in providing support to young people. Often the schemes are used for short-term housing. Contact Depaul Nightstop UK for more details: 0808 808 499.

In a lodging scheme you are likely to be given a licence agreement with sets out the rules under which you can stay there. You must ensure that you pay the rent and comply with the rules.

snippets.description: Private renting
snippets.data:
Finding a home that you can afford to rent doesn’t have to mean finding social housing. There are more properties available in the private rented sector. A private landlord is someone who owns one or more properties that they rent out to tenants.

There are many advantages to renting privately:

  • There are no waiting lists, so you’ll be able to move in quickly
  • You can choose exactly where you want to live
  • There are many different types of property available, from one-bedroom studio flats to houses big enough for large families
  • The properties will usually be well decorated and carpeted; this is often not the case with social housing.
  • The properties often come with a fridge, freezer and washing machine
  • If you’re on a low income, you may be entitled to Housing Benefit which will cover some or all of your rent

The Council offer a Rent Deposit Scheme which can assist clients in securing a property in the private sector by offering financial assistance when paying the rent in advance and deposit. This must pass a few of the Council’s checks, but otherwise will be processed straight to the Landlord. If you secure a property and can demonstrate that it is affordable, please send over documents below to HousingSupport@lewisham.gov.uk for us to assess:

  • Energy Performance Certificate
  • Gas Safety Certificate
  • Tenancy agreement with landlord’s name, client’s name, address of property, monthly rent amount and deposit required.
  • Landlord/agency’s bank details including payee name, payee address, bank name, sort code, account number.
  • Proof of income (proof of receipt of benefits and, if applicable, last 3 months payslips).

snippets.description: Social housing
snippets.data:
Eligibility for a council or housing association home depends on your nationality, immigration status and if you've recently lived abroad.

Complete your online social housing application . If you need help please contact us. You can also read about how we allocate social housing properties.

Some housing associations accept applications directly, but waiting lists are often long. Some housing associations only provide homes for people from particular groups for example, people with disabilities. To find out which housing associations let properties directly you can contact the Regulator of Social Housing.

fields.value: contact us

snippets.description: Social housing in other areas
snippets.data:
Some areas of the country have lower demand for social housing, and if you are prepared to relocate, you could get help much more quickly. If you need to relocate you can apply to as many different councils as you want. However, each council can decide whether to accept an application. Greater priority may be given to people who have a local connection with the area, for example if you:

  • work there
  • used to live there
  • have close relatives in the area

Lewisham Council works with Homefinder UK. Homefinder UK is a national housing mobility scheme available to anyone willing to move nationwide including homeless households, applicants living in temporary accommodation, private sector tenants threatened with homelessness, victims of domestic abuse & grooming, overcrowded families & social tenants.

Homefinder UK helps households who want or need to move to find a home that better matches their household size and personal and financial circumstances. You can find out more information by visiting their website: homefinderuk.org/ ;

snippets.description: Housing co-operatives
snippets.data:
A housing co-operative is housing that is managed and controlled by the people who live there. Rents are usually lower than private tenancies and tenants tend to have stronger rights.

To find housing co-operatives you can contact the Regulator of Social Housing.

snippets.description: Tenancy transfer
snippets.data: If you are a current council or housing association tenant and you want to move to a new home you can apply for a tenancy transfer. Tenancy transfers are dealt with on the basis of housing need, so this will depend on the reasons you want one. In addition your landlord must have accommodation of the right size – larger homes are usually in short supply. You may not be able apply for a tenancy transfer if you, or any member of your household, have been found guilty of antisocial behaviour or you have rent arrears. Your housing officer will be able to give you further advice about transfers.

snippets.description: Buying a home
snippets.data:
Buying a home is only an option if you can realistically afford the mortgage payments. Homeowners have stronger rights than tenants, but home ownership is a big financial commitment. If a homeowner is unable to keep up with their mortgage payments, they will be in danger of losing their home. To save for the deposit you can open a Help to Buy ISA (a savings account). The Government will boost your savings by 25%. So, for every £200 you save, you receive a government bonus of £50. The maximum government bonus you can receive is £3,000. The accounts are available to each first time buyer, not each household. This means that if you are planning to buy with your partner, for example, you could receive a government bonus of up to £6,000 towards your first home. Help to Buy ISA is available from a range of banks, building societies and credit unions.

There are a number of home-ownership schemes to help first time buyers. These include:

  • Shared Ownership - offers you the chance to buy a share of your home (between 25% and 75% of the home’s value) and pay rent on the remaining share. Later on, you could buy bigger shares when you can afford to.
  • Equity Loan - the Government lends you up to 20% of the cost of your newly built home, so you’ll only need a 5% cash deposit and a 75% mortgage to make up the rest.
  • Key workers scheme: A scheme to help people working in essential services buy a home near their work.

Most of the above schemes are run by housing associations. Contact your regional Help to Buy Agent on 0300 5000996 for more information.

The Homes for Londoners property search tool is a new way to find a home to buy or rent in the capital. You can use it to find a range of Shared Ownership, Help to Buy and Rental homes in London.

snippets.description: Sheltered housing
snippets.data: Sheltered housing schemes vary in the level of care they offer. Some have homes for sale, others only for rent. Most schemes have accommodation that is specially adapted for older people and offer emergency assistance services. Some schemes have wardens or other support. To find out about the options contact the Elderly Accommodation Counsel on Freephone 0800 377 70 70.

snippets.description: Almshouses and Abbeyfield
snippets.data:
Almshouses are run by small, independent charitable trusts, many of them established hundreds of years ago and with many of the buildings now listed for their architectural merit. Each charity has its own rules determining which older people it can house and is run by a board of Trustees. For example, some were set up specifically for the workers of a particular local trade or for those in a certain parish. The Almshouse Association manages a list of local Almshouses and contact details.

Abbeyfield offer older people supported living arrangements that are similar to extra care. They also run care homes, some of which offer nursing care or specialist facilities for people with dementia. A key element of Abbeyfield is to address loneliness and so most Abbeyfield houses have a live in house manager and shared main meals. You can search the Abbeyfield site for vacancies.

snippets.description: Buying a retirement home
snippets.data:
Buying a home is only an option if you can realistically afford the mortgage payments. Homeowners have stronger rights than tenants, but home ownership is a big financial commitment. If a homeowner is unable to keep up with their mortgage payments, they will be in danger of losing their home.

Retirement housing for sale may be built by private or non-private developers such as housing associations. These are virtually always leasehold schemes and there will be additional, ongoing costs such as service charges and other running costs that can vary considerably. It is important that potential purchasers understand all of the financial obligations and rules about the scheme that they are buying into. Some housing associations have built shared ownership retirement housing where the person buys a proportion of the property and pays rent for the remainder. Some developers are now developing Lifetime Lease schemes. The older person pays a lump sum (significantly below market value) which buys them the right to live in the property for as long as they wish, but upon death or moving out of the property it reverts back to the company. Elderly Accommodation Counsel (EAC) is a national charity that aims to help older people make informed choices about meeting their housing and care needs.

Another option is Shared Ownership. This offers you the chance to buy a share of your home (between 25% and 75% of the home’s value) and pay rent on the remaining share. Later on, you could buy bigger shares when you can afford to. Contact your regional Help to Buy Agent on 0300 5000996 for more information on this option.

The Homes for Londoners property search tool is a new way to find a home to buy or rent in the capital. You can use it to find a range of Shared Ownership, Help to Buy and Rental homes in London.

snippets.description: Fees charged  - why your notice is invalid
snippets.data:
From 1 June 2019, the Tenant Fees Act 2019 prohibited landlords and agents from charging any fees to tenants, other than those 'permitted' by the Act. Any tenancy that is signed on or after 1 June 2019 must adhere to the new regulations.

The permitted fees are:

  • A holding deposit of maximum 1 weeks rent (which must have been either credited against the rent with your agreement or refunded)
  • A tenancy deposit (maximum of 5 weeks’ rent - unless the annual rent is equal to or greater than £50,000 when up to six weeks deposit is allowed).
  • Payments for utilities, council tax, TV licence if included in the tenancy in agreement
  • Payment for change of tenancy (a maximum of £50 or reasonable costs)
  • Payment of costs for a replacement key
  • Interest of 3% above base rate on late payment of rent

If any other fees have been charged and not repaid to you before the service of the section 21 notice then the notice is not valid.

snippets.description: Category 1 and Category 2 hazards
snippets.data:
The Housing Act 2004 introduced a system for local authorities to assess housing conditions in their area. This is called the Housing Health and Safety Rating System (HHSRS). It helps councils to decide whether a hazard exists at someone’s home which may cause harm to the health or safety of the person living there.

There are 29 housing hazards. If a hazard is a serious and immediate risk to a person's health and safety, this is known as a Category 1 hazard. If a hazard is less serious or less urgent, this is known as a Category 2 hazard.

Hazard

Health Effects

1

Damp and mould growth
Health threats due to dust mites, mould or fungal growth including threats to mental health and social wellbeing associated with damp, humid and mouldy conditions.

Allergies, asthma, effects of toxins from mould and fungal infections

2

Excess cold
Threats to health from cold indoor temperatures. A healthy indoor temperature is 18oC to 21oC.

Respiratory conditions: flu, pneumonia and bronchitis;
Cardiovascular conditions: heart attacks and strokes

3

Excess heat
Threats due to high indoor temperatures.

Dehydration, trauma, stroke, cardiovascular and respiratory problems

4

Asbestos and MMF
Exposure to asbestos fibres and Manufactured Mineral Fibres (MMF).

Asbestos: Damage to lungs
MMF: Damage to skin, eyes and lungs

5

Biocides
Threats to health from chemicals used to treat timber and mould growth.

Risk from breathing in, skin contact and swallowing of the chemical

6

Carbon Monoxide and fuel combustion products
Excess levels of carbon monoxide, nitrogen dioxide, sulphur dioxide and smoke.

Dizziness, nausea, headaches, disorientation, unconsciousness and breathing problems

7

Lead
Threats to health from lead ingestion from paint, water pipes, soil and fumes from leaded petrol.

Lead poisoning causing nervous disorders, mental health and blood production issues

8

Radiation
Health threats from radon gas and its daughters, primarily airborne but also radon dissolved in water.

Lung cancer caused by exposure, the risk of which increases with the amount and length of exposure

9

Uncombusted fuel gas
Threat from fuel gas escaping into the atmosphere within a property.

Suffocation

10

Volatile organic compounds
Threat to health from a diverse group of organic chemicals including formaldehyde that are gaseous at room temperature and can be found in a wide variety of materials in the home.

Allergies, irritation to the eyes, nose and skin, headaches, nausea, dizziness and drowsiness

11

Crowding and space
Hazards associated with lack of space for living, sleeping and normal household or family life.

Psychological distress and mental disorders; increased risk of hygiene issues and accidents; personal space and privacy compromised

12

Entry by intruders
Problems keeping a property secure against unauthorised entry; and problems maintaining defensible space.

Fear of burglary occurring, stress and anguish caused by burglary and injuries caused by the intruder

13

Lighting
Threats to physical and mental health associated with inadequate natural or artificial light, including the psychological effects associated with the view from the property through glazing.

Depression and psychological effects due to lack of natural light. Eyestrain from glare and inadequate light

14

Noise
Threats to physical and mental health due to exposure to noise within the property or within its curtilage.

Psychological and physiological changes resulting from lack of sleep, poor concentration, headaches and anxiety

15

Domestic hygiene, pests and refuse
Health hazards due to poor design, layout and construction making it hard to keep clean and hygienic, attracting pests and inadequate and unhygienic provision for storing household waste.

Stomach and intestinal disease, infection, asthma, allergies, disease from rats and physical hazards

16

Food safety
Threats of infection from poor provision and facilities to store, prepare and cook food.

Stomach and intestinal disease, diarrhoea, vomiting, stomach upset and dehydration

17

Personal hygiene, sanitation and drainage
Threats of infections and threat to mental health associated with personal hygiene, including personal and clothes washing facilities, sanitation and drainage.

Stomach and intestinal disease, skin infections and depression

18

Water supply
Threats to health from contamination by bacteria, parasites, viruses and chemical pollutants due to the quality of water supply for drinking and household use such as cooking, washing and sanitation.

Dehydration, fatigue, headaches, dry skin, bladder infections and legionnaires disease

19

Falls associated with baths
Falls associated with a bath, shower or similar facility.

Physical injuries: cuts, lacerations, swellings and bruising.

20

Falls on the level surfaces
Falls on any level surface such as floor, yards and paths, including falls associated with trip steps, thresholds or ramps where the change in level is less than 300mm.

Physical injuries: bruising, factures, head, brain and spinal injuries

21

Falls associated with stairs and steps
Falls associated with stairs and ramps where the change in level is greater than 300mm. It includes stairs or ramps within a property; or external stairs or ramps associated with the property; access to the property and to shared facilities; or means of escape from fire and falls over stairs, ramp or step guarding.

Physical injuries: bruising, fractures, head, brain and spinal injuries

22

Falls between levels
Falls from one level to another, inside or outside a dwelling where the difference is more than 300mm. Including falls from balconies, landings or out of windows.

Physical injuries

23

Electrical hazards
Hazards from electric shock and electricity burns.

Electric shock and burns

24

Fire
Threats to health from exposure to uncontrolled fire and associated smoke. It includes injuries from clothing catching fire, common when trying to put a fire out.

Burns, being overcome by smoke; or death

25

Flames, hot surfaces and materials
Burns or injuries caused by contact with a hot flame or fire, hot objects and non-water based liquids. Scalds caused by contact with hot liquids and vapours.

Burns, scalds, permanent scarring and death.

26

Collision and entrapment
Risks of physical injuries from trapping body parts in architectural features such as trapping fingers in doors and windows and colliding with objects such as windows, doors and low ceilings.

Physical injuries such as cuts and bruising to the body

27

Explosions Threats from the blast of an explosion, from debris generated by the blast and from partial or total collapse of a building as a result of the explosion.

Physical injuries, crushing, bruising, puncture, fractures, head, brain and spinal injuries.

28

Ergonomics
Threats of physical strain associated with functional space and other features at the dwelling.

Strain and sprain injuries

29

Structural collapse and falling elements
The threat of the dwelling collapsing or part of the fabric being displaced or falling due to inadequate fixing or disrepair or as a result of adverse weather conditions.

Physical injuries

snippets.description: Reasonable timescales for carrying our repairs
snippets.data:
There is no set timescale for all repairs. A reasonable time will depend on a number of factors, including extent of the disrepair, the impact on the occupants, the time of year and the availability of replacement parts. If there is a delay then your landlord should explain the reason.

It may be reasonable to put in place temporary measures (for example electric heaters if your boiler is broken).

If your landlord is the Council or a housing association then you can find their target timescales for repairs on their website.

adviceSets.name: Experiencing domestic abuse
adviceSets.description:
Violence means violence from another person or threats of violence from another person which are likely to be carried out. Violence (whether domestic or other violence) should be interpreted in a broad way to include not just physical violence, but also threatening or intimidating behaviour.

Domestic violence includes threatening behaviour, violence or abuse, whether it be psychological, physical, sexual, financial or emotional.

adviceSets.name: Homelessness legislation
adviceSets.description: There are a number of legal tests and duties that we have to the homeless which are all set out in the links provided.

adviceSets.name: Homeless
adviceSets.description: We must help if you're legally homeless or threatened with homelessness.

adviceSets.name: Threatened with Homelessness
adviceSets.description: We must help if you're legally homeless or threatened with homelessness.

adviceSets.name: Homelessness Due to Violence
adviceSets.description: We must help if you're legally homeless or threatened with homelessness.

adviceSets.name: Eligibility
adviceSets.description: The legislation includes provisions that make certain people from abroad ineligible for housing assistance.

adviceSets.name: Personalised Housing Plan
adviceSets.description: The plan will include actions to be taken by the authority and the applicant to try and prevent or relieve homelessness.

adviceSets.name: The Relief Duty
adviceSets.description: If the applicant is already homeless, or becomes homeless despite activity during the prevention stage, the reasonable steps will be focused on helping the applicant to secure accommodation.

adviceSets.name: Prevention Duty
adviceSets.description: We have a duty to take reasonable steps to help prevent any eligible person (regardless of priority need status, intentionality and whether they have a local connection) who is threatened with homelessness from becoming homeless.

adviceSets.name: Intentionally Homeless
adviceSets.description: Applicants who have a priority need, and whose homelessness has not been successfully relieved, are owed a lesser duty if they have become homeless intentionally than would be owed to them if they were homeless unintentionally. This reflects the general expectation that, wherever possible, people should take responsibility for their own accommodation needs and not behave in a way which might lead to the loss of their accommodation.

adviceSets.name: Local Connection
adviceSets.description: An applicant’s local connection with an area will depend on a number of factors.

adviceSets.name: Reviews and Appeals
adviceSets.description: Housing authorities must provide written notifications to applicants when they reach certain decisions about their case, and the reasons behind any decisions that are against the applicant’s interests.

adviceSets.name: Interim Duty
adviceSets.description: We don't have to offer interim accommodation to everybody that is homeless.

adviceSets.name: Priority Need
adviceSets.description: If we are unable to prevent an applicant from becoming homeless, or to help them to secure accommodation within the ‘relief’ stage, we are required to reach a decision as to whether the applicant has a priority need for accommodation.

adviceSets.name: Main Housing Duty
adviceSets.description: If homelessness is not successfully prevented or relieved, we will owe the main housing duty to applicants who are eligible, have a priority need for accommodation and are not homeless intentionally.

adviceSets.name: Assessment
adviceSets.description: We have a duty to carry out an assessment in all cases where an eligible applicant is homeless or threatened with homelessness.

We will also negotiate with your landlord to try and keep you in your home.
